talk.start.para: —One of the newspaper cartoonists yesterday gave us the ultimate `I'd like to see that' of Australian politics: the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in pigtails and a blue dress, skipping off down the yellow brick road to the sunny land of Oz, where worries melt, I am told, like lemon drops and every resident munchkin is relaxed and comfortable and raking in shares in AMP.

speech.para: But there are always messages between the lines, because who can think of Dorothy without her supporting cast? I look across at this government and I find the audition hall overflowing for the parts of the lion without courage, the tin man without a heart and, perhaps most oversubscribed of all, the scarecrow without a brain. So somewhere over the rainbow, there you will find the Treasurer, far up and away and off with the bluebirds on his technicolour journey, skipping and singing, singing and skipping.

We all have our sustaining fantasies and, listening to this budget on Tuesday night, I realised that we are not in Kansas any more, because only in the Treasurer's fantasies can there be good in this budget surplus, built on a million small deficits in the lives of ordinary people. The teeth not fixed. The pills not bought. The kids in backyard care or the mother out of work. The apprenticeships not found. The holiday not taken because of the cost of a mother's nursing home. The university degree out of reach and the fulfilling career therefore not had. The shame of the young school leaver's hundredth unsuccessful job interview. The corroding despair of the long-term jobless and the alarm of their families. The grief of the parent farewelling a child leaving town for good. The factory closed. The trauma of selling up and moving. The hundred unspoken small goodbyes of ordinary people to their ordinary lives.

These are the human losses on which this accountants' surplus was built by a government that has long since ceased caring and has never learned to care. These indeed are the hard yards. These are the long hauls. The shouldered burden of battling Australians somehow fuels the happiness of a Treasurer long unacquainted with the ordinary needs of his fellow Australians. The griefs and consolations and the quiet unprotested sufferings underpin the triumph of his numbers and the failure of his government's decency.

The government will have you believe that all that pain was essential. It was not. If it was essential, why did Tuesday's budget contain spending increases of $10 billion over the next four years? If it was essential, why is it that when we look at the effect on financial year 1998-99 of the three Costello budgets we find that, in net terms, he cut $6 billion in the first budget, $1 billion in the second and then put back $2 billion in the third? Why didn't the Treasurer explain here on Tuesday why he has effectively run down two flights of stairs and back up one on fiscal policy? He did not because the admission would be too great.

In the first two budgets we had selective leaking and pre-announcement of the bad news. This one has been selective leaking and admission of failure in small instalments, the only instalments a battered, unpopular and fundamentally untrustworthy political outfit can afford. He was wrong and he cannot admit it. But the net effect of this government's policy changes on financial year 1998-99—the net effect of going down two flights of stairs and up one—was $5.4 billion. Subtracting that $5.4 billion from the surplus announced by the Treasurer leaves us with an underlying `no policy change' deficit of $2.7 billion—no cuts, no surcharges, no fees and no pain.

Let me tell you something that my deputy, Gareth Evans, said about an alternative budget strategy for Australia—not this week, not last year, but two years ago after the coalition's first budget. And I quote:

We say we can get to budget balance within a reasonable time—in fact, within the lifetime of this parliament, by 1998-99—with a much less savage budget strategy . . . We can get to that by targeting savings of no more than $3 billion by that third year.

In other words, $1 billion of new savings each year in three budgets would have produced a starting point surplus this year of at least $300 million. On top of this, the higher economic growth, which Labor's budget strategy would have allowed, would have seen a 1998-99 budget surplus of similar dimensions to the one announced on Tuesday.

Our argument was then, as it is today, that fiscal consolidation in the economic climate this government faced in 1996 was necessary but did not need to be nearly as harsh as what they immediately embarked upon. We had to get that budget back into balance but we did not need to take the harsh measures you took. We need surpluses of the kind that Labor delivered four years in a row, not long after inheriting a $25 billion deficit from the then Treasurer, John Howard—surpluses built on jobs and growth. John Howard told that electorate, back in 1983, that things were fine when he had on his desk a briefing note from the Treasury of a $25 billion deficit. We put that budget into surplus and we provided universal health care and we provided tax cuts and we dramatically increased higher education.

We need to retire public debt, but we must keep that issue in perspective too. Despite what the Jeremiahs might say, Australia's fiscal position was very good by international standards when this government came into office. That is not to say that we should become complacent—we should not—but it does seriously question why, for example, the government would sell Telstra to reduce what in our last year in government was the third lowest public sector debt in the industrialised world. That debt as a percentage of GDP was less than half Canada's and two-thirds the proportion of France, Germany, the United States and even Britain after a decade of Maggie Thatcher's budget cutting and privatisations. This government inherited the third lowest public debt in the industrialised world and they want to sell Telstra to take us to the second lowest.

Why then should we allow up to $20 billion worth of Telstra, this great national asset, to go to foreigners? After only four years we will lose more in Telstra dividends than we will save on our interest bill; dividends that would otherwise be there for generations to pay for hospitals and schools, railways and roads. This budget puts aside $580 million for the financial managers as costs and commissions for the Telstra float—$580 million to sell Australia's patrimony. That is more than half a billion dollars we could save tomorrow and keep a great national asset into the bargain.

In any budget that spends money like this one there are things to be welcomed and we should offer praise where it is due. Two praiseworthy ideas are the extension of the gold card to all World War II veterans and the extension of the health care card to more self-funded retirees. Labor was proud to establish both cards in our time in government. It is unfortunate, however, that benefits for a small number of our retirees should accompany reductions for the vast majority. Twenty times as many have experienced those reductions as have now received benefits.

Furthermore, had those self-funded retirees obtained their card under Labor, they would have had access to free dental care, lower priced prescriptions and free hearing aids. Those are the benefits those self-funded retirees would have had, with the rest of the pensioners, if the system had been extended under the terms and conditions that operated under Labor. But even so, with this so-called gesture to the elderly that is supposed to be contained within this budget, 220,000 benefit, four million lose. But all of them—those who benefit and those who do not—now confront a massive expense on entry to essential care in nursing homes.

Our specific policies will be announced closer to the election, but I can say two things: we will restore capital funds cut from nursing homes in full and none of our retirees—or any other Australian, for that matter—will have to pay a GST on any of their goods or services.

But even though this budget has spent some money it leaves too many questions unanswered. It cannot answer the people who ask themselves what all the pain was for in the first place or why someone else's pain was more worthy of being reversed than was theirs. How precisely did the government make the decision not to restore Commonwealth dental funding? How did it decide it was relaxed about the situation of one woman whose letter to the Liberal member for Gilmore (Mrs Gash) was submitted to a recent Senate inquiry—a woman who had been informed that all her teeth needed to be extracted? Despite living in constant pain, it will be 18 months before she can be treated. Even then, she will have to wait for each individual tooth to cause her pain before she is entitled to have that tooth extracted. What thought process, what overarching philosophy, what quality of mercy goes into that kind of decision?

How did the government decide it was relaxed about elderly Australians in their hour of greatest fragility still having to sell the family home to pay for entry into a nursing home—that after all the backflips and reversals (some 14 of them) the fees remain, the government still circles the family homes of our elderly. How did it decide that it could go right ahead and spend that money elsewhere—$150 million a year?

How did it decide there was no relief for women forced out of the work force by spiralling child-care fees? How did it decide instead to factor their despair into its employment projections? The bad employment estimates in this budget are still heroic. At a minimum they only stand up because of the thousands of women driven out of the work force by this government's decisions on child care. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) thinks that that is about family values; it is not. It is simply a collapse in the living standards of middle and low income working families.

How, after all its claims, can there not be one single dollar more for public hospitals in this budget than was on the table when the Premiers walked out on the Commonwealth's last offer in disgust? Let me say to John Hewson, who seems to have picked the impact of the Asian crisis far better than this government, that he was absolutely right when he said today that this health offer is nothing like the 15 per cent over five years touted by this government. This government deals dishonestly with the states, but in dealing dishonestly with the states it deals dishonestly with the thousands on waiting lists.

There is one large group of Australians which suffers most from these three budgets. I am speaking, of course, of the unemployed. To see why, we need to remember the level of economic growth before John Howard came into power—the level of economic growth, and the economy as a whole, that John Howard was pleased to describe to international bankers when he came into power as having inherited an economy better than good in parts. In the financial year 1993-94 Labor's growth figure was 4.6 per cent. In 1994-95 it was 4.4 per cent. In 1995-96 it was 4.1 per cent. Australia's economic growth rate for John Howard's first full financial year in office was just 2.7 per cent.

We had four per cent growth plus under Labor; not even two-thirds of that in the first year under the coalition. And we are meant to accept that this pathetic performance had nothing to do with the entire government frontbench preaching economic doom for a full five months before the first budget in 1996 and nothing to do with that budget which took $27 billion out of the economy over four years? Growth got above the parapet of three per cent last year, and now it has been forecast to flatline back at three per cent, with unemployment stuck around eight per cent.
But when the Treasurer was asked about the unemployment rate on Tuesday night, this is what the Treasurer of this nation said on the unemployment rate, boasting about his budget:
No, it bounces around a bit. You know, it's 7.9, it's 8, it's 8.1. We think it's around the 8 mark at the moment . . . but it will bounce. It's been bouncing for a year.

I am sick of that kind of talk. I am sick of people like the Treasurer, with a screen full of teeth, making glib analogies about real lives. These are real people, Mr Treasurer, not footballs, not Dr Kemp's rubbery statistics. They are real mums and dads with real children dependent on them trying to get a start in life. You were not elected to bounce unemployment around. You were elected to get it down.

Before March 1996 the unemployment rate had been falling for three years. This government came in and worsened the unemployment position immediately. In our last two years in government, Labor created 550,000 jobs. In his first two years, John Howard created not half as many. The difference was 315,000 people—three MCGs jam-packed full of people who would now be in work and not on the dole queue if the coalition had just managed to keep up the pace we set. And anything it has managed to do on unemployment, or might manage, has to be judged against another MCG crowd of nearly 100,000 people who have simply given up looking for work since this government came into office.

And what of those left on the dole queue longer than they ever feared because of the growth this government put on hold? The number of people unemployed for a year or more fell by over a third during Labor's last term in office. So far, during this government's term, it has actually risen. This is a stroke of true genius—it has actually risen. When you started cutting into skillshare and other labour market programs in May 1996, there were 206,000 long-term unemployed Australians. Figures released this morning show that their ranks have now increased by 33,000 people as a result of this government's policies. Long-term unemployed used to be a quarter of all unemployed. Today they are a third and rising.

And they have been ill-served by a government which has wrecked the support systems and put long-term unemployed people into work—exemplary programs emulated around the world put on the scrap heap; or, worse, some of them put into the hands of people with no office, no staff, no experience, some without even a telephone! It cares more about an $8 million expenditure of public funds to boast its wares than it did about effective delivery to the long-term unemployed.

This is where we count the cost of this budget. Having counted the beans, the government has closed the book on Australian families. It is not going to redress the pain of the last two years. It is not going to tell them where it wants to take them next century. As far as this government is concerned, there are only two more stops in the journey—the GST and an election.

So let me talk about their GST—the dead heart of the hidden tax package. John Howard has built a career avoiding the unequivocal, but three years ago this month he was absolutely unequivocal. These are his words, and we remember them:
No, there's no way a GST will ever be part of our policy . . . Never, ever. It's dead. It was killed by the voters at the last election.

talk.start.para: —That was three years ago.

—The Treasurer says to me that it was three years ago. When was three years ago? Just before the last election. Peter Costello has built a career avoiding being quiet, but his budget speech was silent on the issue of a GST. He was like Basil Fawlty: `Don't mention the war!' Don't mention the GST!

speech.para: The budget papers on Tuesday included $20 million for the administration of this tax package, so we are now in the farcical situa tion where the coalition will tell us what it will cost to implement the tax package but it will not tell us what is in it. But one thing is for sure: the GST has come back when no-one thought it would. This tax on jobs, this tax on the poor, this tax on families is back. As we prepare for its stealthy arrival, we need to remember that it comes back with none of the integrity that was there in its initial presentation, when John Hewson put out his fully costed package, openly and frankly, more than a year out from an election.

John Howard told his party two days ago that we could be in the last parliamentary session before an election. Just weeks to go, but the voters are not going to see the tax package yet. It is something to be dropped and then scuttled away from to the polls before anyone can get the wrapping off and find out what is underneath.

That changes where we stand as a party. Those of us who oppose a GST now have only one course of action. I want to make it quite clear tonight that the Labor Party believes that John Howard has forfeited any right ever to claim a legitimate mandate for his GST. And our opposition will be there whether we win or lose the next election. A vote for Labor is a guaranteed vote against the GST. If we are elected, you will not get one, and if we are in opposition we will oppose it in the Senate.

We do this because the lateness of the hour means we are expected to take the Prime Minister on trust. But we see nothing in this government's record to trust that the package will be fair or equitable. The Treasurer has explicitly refused in this place to rule out a GST on the following items: doctors' bills, dentists' bills, school fees, university fees, power bills, food, nursing home fees; local government and water rates; and even rent.

And we see nothing in this government's record to trust that its awesome complexity would become, in their hands, anything other than a complete disaster—a disaster for businesses, workers, and all consumers—implemented in the usual manner, with all the grace and poise of Inspector Clouseau in a ball-bearing factory. We refuse to help John Howard get his agenda into place and we will not inflict his tax on the Australian people.

Modern government, as we approach a new century, is about skills, innovation, infrastructure and exports. It is not about bean counting. It is not simply about achieving a surplus by any means. It is about achieving a surplus in periods of moderate economic growth at the same time as creating a modern, successful state which rewards, advances and enhances excellence. For Australians, this means recognising something about our own country. It means recognising that many other countries have advantages we do not. We are a nation in nobody's trading bloc. We make our own way in a region where the big countries are growing by an amount equivalent to our entire population every single year, while we occupy a great proportion of that region's real estate. It also means recognising what makes us proud to be Australians—our history of innovation, our scientific endeavour and our national courage.

Too often, as we have approached issues of reform over the last 15 years or so, we have been critical of Australians' willingness to work hard, innovate and change based on their own convictions, rather than on some official view. Too often, we have underestimated how much Australians pride and value their own work and their achievements. Too few Australians, too few members of this House, know that Victoria and South Australia combined have won more Nobel Prizes in the sciences than Japan.

Government must value and enhance those great Australian characteristics. Microeconomic reform is not about depriving people of wages, depriving people of leisure, depriving people of things which make for a constructive family life. We must be about enhancing skills, building on our record of innovation and developing our outward-looking attitude to opportunities in our region. Just try to find anything substantial in these three budgets from this government which builds on any of those strengths and does not detract from them.

Instead, the vast bulk of savings made in three budgets have been at the expense of this Australia. They have come from our universi ties, from labour market programs helping to keep our population permanently skilled, from research and development incentives and from assistance to exporters to gain a foothold in international markets.

The effects are clearly documented in this budget. It forecasts a drop in net export growth. It shows business investment growth slowing throughout the year. Recent figures show growth in business spending on research and development, which reached an all-time record of $4.3 billion in Labor's last year, stopped dead for the first time in a decade following the swinging cuts to R&D support in the coalition's first budget.

This is why there is no point in delivering a surplus ringed by deficits. A surplus bought from the million deficits in family budgets. A surplus sitting alongside a level of foreign debt which has worsened by $28 billion since the coalition came into power, and with a current account deficit forecast to grow by another $31 billion over the coming year—and nearly every single independent analyst thinking that is an understatement.

This is why we need a government with a broader vision, why we need a government that will restore the balance and why we need a government that sees where it can forge a partnership with the Australian people: a partnership supporting family life, supporting the unemployed, supporting industry, supporting investment and supporting exporters. We need partnership and we need to have ambitions as well.

Two years have told us all we need to know about John Howard's ambitions for Australia. He wants an Australia with him as Prime Minister, and that is where his vision ends. He wants an Australia moulded into the shape he thinks will keep him there—a nation riddled by division, neatly carved up into the few groups whose dislike of each other, encouraged by this government, he thinks, will keep him in power forever.

Labor will go into this next election believing in a different Australia. We believe in a proud, confident and intelligent Australia. Labor believes in an Australia that wants security in its workplaces, peace of mind in a strong health system and opportunity flow ing from an education system which gives its citizens the best chance they can get in a global economy. We understand with absolute clarity the importance of the Asian financial crisis for the Australian economy—described last year by the Treasurer as `scarcely measurable'—and the corresponding need for fiscal restraint in that environment.

I promised back in February that Labor would deliver three underlying surpluses in our first term in government, and that promise stands as long as this government's projections for the budgetary position and economic forecasts stand. But Labor is going to look at priorities. We are going to look at where this government has spent money wastefully and at where the money could be used more intelligently and to greater benefit for greater numbers of Australians. We are not going into this election year with a fistful of dollars as a grudging apology for pain rendered over the previous three years. We are going into this election year with a vision of where we want Australia to go, what Australians want in their everyday lives and how, within the means available to us, we can go in that direction.

These three budgets have sacrificed the security and opportunity of our population to Liberal Party prejudices. This is a government that has forgotten its responsibility to govern for all Australians and is now prepared to experiment with an unfair, job destroying tax in a period of great uncertainty—an appalling time to introduce such a tax. In the last two years, over the last three budgets, the Australian people have learned what they were getting when they elected this government. I maintain that they deserved something better than what they got.

Normally, it would be hard to close the book on a government after only three budgets. Normally, it would be hard to say a government is not worth considering again, when it has only been around for two years. Normally, a first-term government just turns up in the queue for another term like it is waiting for dessert. But this isn't a normal government. This isn't the normal run of events at all. This is John Howard's government and John Howard's Australia.

We know that millions of Australians want no more to do with this government: no more of this government that loses seven ministers in just 18 months; no more of this government that puts black shirts, balaclavas and dogs on chains in our workplaces; no more of this government that defends ministers with tens of millions of dollars in their family trusts and that wants working Australians to pay a GST on their grocery bills and their clothing, their rent and their rates; and no more of this government with a quarter of a billion dollars for companies that want to sack all their workers—ignoring the legalities—and nothing for those who want to keep them on.

Well, these were your three budgets and they're over. If there was a time and a place for a government as harsh and chaotic as this, it is long past and in another, lesser country. And if there is a place for it now to go, it is out: out of our lives and out for good.
A disturbance having occurred in the gallery—

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —Monday, 4 May, was an historic day for workers and the trade union movement. The victory, emphasised by the High Court's affirmation, cannot be underestimated. Three separate court decisions in four weeks recognised fairness, decency and justice. In short, these decisions recognised the Australian way.

speech.para: The decision to order the reinstatement of 2,000 illegally sacked waterfront workers was an outright repudiation of the sneaky, shallow, murky, smelly and underhand way the workers and their statutory rights were violated by Patrick Stevedores and the National Farmers Federation.

The Howard government, particularly the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), supported and endorsed at each step the strategy of Patrick and the NFF. Ideological and pathological unsustainable hatred so wilfully practised by the Howard government is no substitute for the right to freedom of association by workers and the role of trade unions. This is the real story of the court decisions over the past four weeks.

On Friday, 8 May, I joined many workers, unionists and community members at the gateway of No. 6 jetty at Port Kembla to welcome back on the job the illegally sacked waterfront workers. It was a moment of triumph. Despite the bitter, frustrating fight, it was a moment of enormous pride to see those workers walk through the gates which had been closed to them four weeks earlier. I paid tribute to those workers on Friday, and I restate that tribute today. Through quiet, dignified resolve, each of those illegally sacked workers and their families took on a fight and won.

Throughout the dispute and for two years prior to it, the Port Kembla workers were subjected to daily ridicule, attack and abuse by the minister. To their credit, along with each of their colleagues in terminals around Australia, they stood their ground for their rights, the survival of the union they choose to belong to and for workers everywhere. They stood at the front line to defend decency and fairness, because they understood that ultimately, if they were defeated, no worker was safe.

I pay tribute to the leadership of Mark Armstrong, the secretary of the MUA at Port Kembla. I have always had a good working relationship with Mark. To see him deal with the pressures of this dispute, accepting the burden to fight for his members' rights, was incredible. He led with a cool, level head and grace under pressure.

The dispute also brought unexpected focus on the potential of Port Kembla. For the first time in 12 years Port Kembla has handled containers. In the last few weeks Port Kembla has handled more than 2,000. We also saw the establishment of Port Kembla Stevedoring cooperating with the MUA and its members—the same union and the same workers that Patrick, the NFF and Minister Reith hate so much.

Port Kembla has once again shown that it can meet expectations during a crisis. An efficient, effective port was put to the ultimate test and passed it. The Illawarra has always been a united community led, without apology, by the labour movement. We are united when attacked by anyone. We will continue to be united, no matter what the attack or its source. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise today to say a few words about the pernicious fly-ins to inland Queensland. The three statistical divisions of inland Queensland have lost population in the last five years, as seen in the last census. The populations of all of the major towns in the central west and the mid-west—inland Queensland, if you like—are down about 40 per cent, on average, from where they were some 20 or so years ago. We are watching the complete annihilation of the population of inland Australia—other areas are no different from Queensland.

speech.para: In fact, if you take a narrow 60 kilometre band off the east coast of Australia and drop off most of Victoria and a little bit around Adelaide and Perth, you still have a map of Australia and about 90 per cent of the continental land mass. Yet that 90 per cent of the continental land mass is occupied by the same population numbers that were here when Captain Cook arrived. There are about 500,000 people now, and there were about 300,000 people when Captain Cook arrived here. Mr Deputy Speaker, we really are not doing a good job in this country.

One of the great ways that we have of turning this around is in our mining towns. In this, the most enlightened government and the most successful government in Australian history by every measure that one can find was the Bjelke-Petersen government in Queensland. People voted with their feet. We doubled our population with people coming from your states. People made the decision with their feet. They said, `We don't like your states. We don't like your government. We are going to Queensland.' In that period, we doubled the average weekly earnings in the state of Queensland. In the last 12 years, your government took the average weekly earnings down by two per cent and increased the top 20 per cent by 30 per cent. So when you laugh, just check on your figures and you will find that you have a very sad tale to tell. Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish I could go sideways, but I cannot.

In Western Australia, as far as prosperity goes—I do not know about other aspects—the Charles Court government was one of the most successful governments in Australian history. Both those governments banned fly-ins and the pernicious regime of fly-ins to the mining towns is destroying family life. It is destroying the heart and soul of this country. It is placing great dangers upon these people and it is delivering a most inefficient mining industry to Australia, one of our most important industries. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is a privilege to follow the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and talk on the issue of jobs, an issue that I am sure is a little less close to his heart than it was, given that his government has closed the CES in Mareeba. This is indicative of its tendency to shut CESs around the country and indicative of what I believe is its lack of commitment to do anything meaningful for Australia's rising numbers of unemployed. I say rising unemployment because, even though the figures issued last week were 7.9 per cent, the government's own budget forecast put unemployment for the course of the next financial year at eight per cent, which means clearly it is going to rise—
—Less than eight per cent.

—Clearly it has got to rise to eight per cent. Clearly it has got to rise to 8.1 or 8.2 per cent if it is to average eight per cent over the course of the next year. Let me also say that, in its first two years of office, the Howard government has only created 25 per cent of full-time jobs that were created by the outgoing Labor government in the last two years of its office. The Howard government's decision to ignore Australia's unemployed, for what is now three consecutive budgets, shows very clearly that it has got no real desire, drive or plan to create jobs for the unemployed of this country.
—What about Job Network?

—The member for Fisher asked me what about Job Network. My office is overwhelmed by calls—in fact we would get one call at least per day, which is a significant number—with people complaining about the new job placement arrangements. I had a letter from a woman this week—and the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) might take due heed of this—whose son is registered as unemployed. He is waiting on an interview with Centrelink, but he needs to receive a benefit before Employment National will assist him with job placement—a parlous and disgraceful situation. His mother writes, `Our society is forgetting about people, especially those who politicians have little interest in, the unemployed and those with little money. I think the sooner the Liberals stop damaging what caring programs we have, the better.'

speech.para: Those sentiments are reflected across my electorate of Isaacs. People know that this government has now had three chances to do something positive. Three strikes and they are clearly out. They are out of ideas and I am sure they will be voted out of office at the next election based on their disgraceful performance on the issue of job creation because, on their own figures, unemployment will rise over the course of the next financial year.

talk.start.para: —I wish to place on the record just how much this government has done for older Australians and also to make the point that there are so many people in my electorate of Moreton who have been constant in their contribution by raising with me so many of the issues that were ignored for so long by the previous government, which have now been addressed and dealt with over three budgets by this government.

speech.para: Let us look at total aged care funding by the coalition. It is now more than $4 billion a year. There has been announced a $280 million staying at home care and support for older Australians package, specifically to support older Australians in their own homes. A tax rebate to the value of the pensioner tax rebate has been introduced for self-funded retirees, a tax break of $1,299 per year. We are rebuilding nursing homes, with a $20 million package.

The national industry restructuring package targets nursing homes most in need. And, boy, weren't there nursing homes in need? The previous government presided over a drop in capital funding of approximately 75 per cent during its last four years in office. In fact, when we came to power, the Howard government found that 13 per cent of nursing homes did not meet fire regulations, 11 per cent of nursing homes did not meet health regulations and 51 per cent of nursing home residents were sharing their bedroom with three or more people. Is it any wonder we had to act.

The good news for people such as self-funded retirees in my electorate is that finally there is a government in this country prepared to do something for them and give them some dignity, some reward for their effort in saving for their retirement. The seniors health card is now available to an additional 220,000 self-funded retirees. That is simply because the income test threshold has been raised to $40,000 for singles and to $67,000 for couples. That means that there are many self-funded retired people in my electorate of Moreton who will be paying $3.20 a script for 52 scripts a year, and then they are free.

There is also a free flu vaccine for over-65s, and age pensioners and war widows now have a government in power prepared to tie—in law—their income, their pensions, to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. On top of that, World War II veterans finally have a government that is prepared to provide a gold card to those over 70 who faced danger from hostile forces.

Those simple measures that have provided dignity to older Australians are proof positive that there is a government that is not only listening constituent by constituent, electorate by electorate, but also taking a whole of government approach to older Australians. We have delivered for older Australians and it is right that we do so.

talk.start.para: —I rise to draw the Main Committee's attention to the answer to a question I put on notice to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), No. 2701. That question concerned the expansion of Israeli settlements in the Palestinian Arab territories occupied by Israel since 1967. I think that what we see at the moment with the breakdown and impasse in the Middle East peace process is a tragedy for both Israelis and Palestinians, and indeed for everyone in the region and the world.

speech.para: At a time when we see peace being advanced in Northern Ireland and on other most difficult questions such as Cyprus, in the Middle East the expansion of these settlements is against the interests of both the Israeli population and the Palestinian population. They have a legitimate aspiration to have a state of Palestine created within the borders which have been occupied since 1967. Whilst there are no doubt legitimate concerns for the security of Israel and I certainly support the right of Israel to exist within those secure borders, the settlement activity is a breach of the prospect for peace in that region.

I am particularly concerned that perhaps Australians are playing a bad role in the settlement activity. I am concerned at the possibility that tax exempt funds from Australia are being used to assist settler groups in these occupied territories. In the city of Hebron, for example, where there are 400 Israeli settlers and where settlements continue to expand in a very provocative way, the massacre of 27 people occurred in the mosque last year. I am concerned to find that there is almost a shrine to that mass murderer in the settlement area of Hebron. It is that sort of provocation which does nothing to advance the cause of peace in the region.

There is a need for the extremists on both sides of the debate, whether they be Israeli or Palestinian, to be sidelined because unless the Oslo peace accord is proceeded with and peace advanced there can be no security for either Israelis or Palestinians in the region.

talk.start.para: —On 5 April, on a bright, sunny, autumn afternoon, a group of young people and interested adults joined together in what was classed as the Lilley Youth Forum Conference. On 26 March I spoke in this place about the run-up to the Lilley youth conference and listed what was going to happen there. I would like to report back that the whole exercise was an outstanding success. The young people there expressed their views and opinions openly and freely, and they were very grateful that they had a `hotline' to the government and were able to get their message across to their parliamentary representative.

speech.para: One of the more interesting resolutions that was passed on that day was one where they asked that a school counsellor be provided in their schools for each school year; these counsellors would be to meet the needs of the young people. The resolution was that these counsellors or mentors would be able to be contracted for a five-year term and would follow a grade through the whole school, throughout the whole time that that grade was in school, and follow their progress. The feeling was that these counsellors would then get to know the students and would be able to help and assist in times of stress and in times of family problems, if they arose.

It was suggested that these counsellors would also be able to help guide the students in choices of careers and with follow-on programs after they left school. They were very keen that the same person would follow them through the five years they were in high school. They felt that being left alone, and having changes every year, they did not get the consistency that they would if they had the same counsellor for that length of time. I thought it was a very commendable and very worthwhile comment.

Among the speakers who were there were Professor Cheryl Hurst, who was Queenslander of the Year this year. Professor Hurst is also Chancellor at QUT. She spoke very strongly on the need for children and young people to stay at school and to gain their education. But she also emphasised the fact that there needs to be education in the form of life skills. It is very important that we start looking at programs whereby young people are taught, from a very early age, some of the life skills and other things they will need to face the outside world.

Some of the things that they did suggest would be further training, which this government has implemented, and life experience programs for all people. They feel that the transition period between primary, secondary and tertiary education needs to be looked at and programs implemented for that. All in all, there were in the vicinity of 12 resolutions passed. (Time expired)

debateinfo.title: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 2 April 1998, on motion by Mr Vaile:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1998 and the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1998 are both very straightforward and are supported by the opposition.

speech.para: The Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1998 creates an opportunity for people with vehicles registered under the Interstate Road Charge Act 1985 to register their vehicles for periods of less than one year. The opposition supports this. The value of this amendment is that there are certain groups in the community, particularly farmers, who will have vehicles that require registration that they may need to use only for a certain proportion of the year—in other words, for seasonal use. It is unduly oppressive to ask them to register these vehicles for an entire year when they may only be used for three or four months of the year. This legislation creates an opportunity for the vehicles to be registered only for a portion of the year, and we support that.

The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1998 is similarly straightforward. It provides for the recognition of ACT self-government and brings the ACT into the uniform national road transport scheme. It also provides for certain technical amendments to penalties which ensures that provisions with respect to the ACT are brought into line with the rest of the country. The opposition also supports this legislation.

talk.start.para: —I wish to contribute to this cognate debate on the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1998 and the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1998 . Road transport reform is vital to Australia. There is little point in having highly efficient mining and agricultural industries, industries that are vital to Queensland in particular, if the product cannot be exported in the most efficient way possible, and the Howard-Fischer government is committed to transport reform to bring this about.

speech.para: At this very moment we are addressing reform on the waterfront, a major impediment in the transport chain. Current waterfront practices are a barrier to efficiency and competitiveness and cost jobs and economic growth in the whole of Australia. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) has said in this House many times that our government has promised to fix up the waterfront—its rorts, its inefficiencies and its archaic work practices.

We are absolutely determined to do all in our power to promote greater competition in the stevedoring industry. Our international competitiveness depends on achieving this goal. The potential benefits of road transport and waterfront reform are of vital significance to our national interests.

The government is determined to address inefficiency because delays and uncertainties are bad news for the transport industry and small business, and that is why the Howard government is acting to improve the Australian transport system. The government aims to create a productive and reliable transport sector that contributes to economic growth, job creation and greater opportunities for business. This reform process will encourage spirited and real competition across the nation.

Governments across Australia must keep up with and embrace change. For example, the road transport industry may develop a new motor or suspension system for a vehicle which is then immediately taken up by transport operators, but since federation, governments across the land have not been able to pass uniform transport legislation.

National uniform rules will give Australia world's best practice in every area of transport. The government's industrial relations reforms, supported by Cheryl Kernot, provide the necessary framework to address this important area. However, there are regulatory impediments to road transport efficiency.

Phil Russell, who owns a large transport company in my electorate of Lilley, says that despite the fact that all his vehicles are registered and licensed in Queensland and conform to all the rules and regulations of the state, when they travel 150 kilometres south into New South Wales they are then subjected to a new set of authorities, standards, licences and permissions. One minute you are operating within the law, the next minute you are acting outside it.

He says the dangerous goods licence is another example of inefficiency. Companies need a separate licence to travel into New South Wales and again another licence to use vehicles for dangerous goods in Victoria. Why is it when you cross an invisible line, a state border, you can be operating outside the law? I agree with the former Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, when he described this situation as a total nonsense.

These inconsistencies have been a total nightmare and a blight on Australia's transport industry. The work of the National Road Transport Commission and the passage of the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1998 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1998 will provide the greatest improvement since the 1950s when free trade across state borders was supported in the High Court.

The Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1998 has provisions to include flexibility in road vehicle registration. For example, it contains a charge formula for the registration of vehicles for less than one year; it provides for shorter periods to be utilised by operators such as farmers to register vehicles seasonally to transport crops, and for smaller operators balancing cash flow by paying charges quarterly; it provides for 10 priority initiatives from the Ministerial Council on Road Transport Second Heavy Vehicle Reform Package; it returns all revenue from charges to states and territories for road maintenance; and it clarifies the inconsistencies in the treatment of short-term registrations between jurisdictions that have caused a number of constituent complaints. This last measure should limit the problems for farmers and small operators to some extent.

The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1998 deals with the administrative amendments related to the appointment of inspectors to take into account the ACT self-government. It also reduces penalties for excess load masses from 3,000 to 2,000 to comply with the Crimes Act of 1914, where penalty for a corporation should be five times that of an individual.

In my state of Queensland, we need to have access to a flexible transport regime. Unfortunately, the ALP supports 1950 work practices so it is doubly important that the federal government works on reforms that will produce real gains and jobs for Australians.

The challenge for Australia and the transport sector is to produce excellence. The coalition is working with industry to maximise and foster best practices and, unlike the Labor Party, we do not support the inefficient work practices of unions such as the MUA.

Regulation of industry is necessary and the coalition government has been working in participation with industries to create real gains for all Australians. However, we cannot ask industry to be innovative and competitive and accede to government regulations without removing unnecessary regulatory impediments.

The road transport industry is showing that it can and will compete in the world's best practice and the challenge is on for all Australian governments to help them meet this goal. We must produce world's best practice regulations and not tolerate the myriad of conflicting state regulatory regimes.
The Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1998 and the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1998 are small steps in producing government best practice.

talk.start.para: —But important ones.

—Very important ones. Efficiency should be at the forefront of business and governments have a responsibility to regulate because business and many people's jobs are dependent on the cooperation of all Australian governments. I must compliment the Road Transport Commission for their determination to ensure better uniform standards on the roads to the benefit of all Australians.
—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is my great pleasure to sum up on behalf of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile), who is hard at work and due back shortly.
—He is always hard at work.
—He is always hard at work. Can I just say that while there has not been quantity of speakers today, there has been quality and the previous speaker summed this up very well.

speech.para: I think the important part is that there are a number of people in my electorate, as indeed there will be many farmers throughout Australia, who will appreciate the fact that we have moved these provisions. By reducing times available, we will see that there will be reduced costs for farmers and others such as small operators who may wish to opt for three-monthly intervals on registration charge payments to help maintain their cash flow.

These are good measures. The government believes that its reform agenda in relation to road transport has been important. It was a matter that we came into government promising. We have delivered on that. Minister Vaile is driving this process very hard with the states and territories and it is a further example of the government's commitment to road transport reform.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

That the bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY BILL 1998

cognateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (LICENCE CHARGES) BILL 1998
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1998
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (LICENCE CHARGES) BILL 1998
AUSTRALIAN RADIATION PROTECTION AND NUCLEAR SAFETY (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 8 April, on motion by Ms Worth:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —My colleague the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), may have the opportunity to participate in this debate later if he arrives. In his absence, I am very happy to take this matter for the opposition. This bill principally concerns protecting the health and safety of the public from the harmful effects of radiation.

speech.para: The bill establishes the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency and a licensing scheme for the regulation of nuclear installations operated by the Commonwealth or Commonwealth entities, from construction right through all stages of operation to decommissioning. The licensing scheme also extends to the regulation of ionising sources and certain non-ionising sources and establishes the Radiation Health and Safety Advisory Council.

These are entirely reasonable and laudable objectives and the opposition has no intention of opposing the bill. Indeed, we wish to support it. There are a number of matters though which the bill raises which I think could well be addressed by the government, either in the reply to summing up this debate or in another place. The explanatory memorandum, for example, refers to the council membership being drawn from state and territory health agencies, peak industry groups, scientific and technical experts and consumer groups, but the make-up of the council is not specified in the bill at all and is left entirely to ministerial discretion.

We would certainly raise some concerns about the way in which that is left open and the fact that it does not include any members of the public—for example, consumer interests which might be represented by those living adjacent to the established nuclear facilities like Lucas Heights. A local government council, the Sutherland Shire, would have a very substantial interest in nuclear safety and matters associated with that. It would not be at all unreasonable for groups like that to be represented in the decision making apparatus established by this bill.

There are also quite extensive powers provided for the inspectors under section 53. While the wording of this section is eminently reasonable on the face of it, these are quite extensive powers. There are few limitations on the way in which they can be exercised under the bill. The opposition would want to question the extent of those powers arising in cases, but not where there is a serious issue of nuclear safety arising because there we would want all those powers to be available. There are few limitations which restrict them. They might be available to be used under circumstances which are not as desirable as those where there is a nuclear safety question arising.

I think there are a couple of issues which we would like to see further discussed in relation to this bill. Whether that takes place at the summing up here or in another place is a matter which can be left to the discretion of the government at this stage. Certainly we will be raising those issues again.

The whole question of nuclear safety and the establishment of Commonwealth nuclear facilities is the central matter behind this bill's creation. The opposition does have some concerns with regard to broader policy in respect of nuclear facilities in Australia. Australia has never been a nuclear power in the sense that we have sought nuclear weapons or sought to use the nuclear fuel cycle to generate electricity. However, we have for many years now had a nuclear facility in the form of the research reactor at Lucas Heights.

When this facility was first established, the Cold War was very much in operation and many people were concerned about issues of nuclear security from the point of view of nuclear weapons production. Australia did not have a public policy of moving into this area in the years following the war, but quite clearly it would have been in the background of government decisions at the time. Indeed, while I personally believe that that was never an option for Australia, one can understand why a government might, in the climate of the day, have those issues in its mind and want to establish a research reactor which, while ostensibly being for medical and other nuclear research purposes, could serve an alternative purpose if government thought that an urgent necessity at the time.

Those days, though, are now well past. Indeed, the world is moving against the nuclear fuel cycle and against nuclear weapons, most specifically. Events in India in the past few days have amply demonstrated the world's view about those states which move towards nuclear weapon status. That is something that we all in this parliament condemn, and I know that the government and the opposition will indeed be making their views even clearer on this in the days ahead, as will all of the other states of the world that support the nuclear non-proliferation treaty.

We are left with the question of Lucas Heights. Unfortunately, the reactor there has only a limited life left to it. The current Nuclear Safety Bureau is refusing to relicense that reactor after 2003-2005. In that period, the reactor will cease to function, because it would not be particularly safe to continue to operate it, given its age. It is a perfectly reasonable end to the reactor's life cycle: all things have a cycle in their existence, and nuclear reactors might normally be expected not to operate for quite so long.

Indeed, ANSTO has managed to extract the maximum value for the Australian dollar from that facility over the very many years in which the reactor has been in operation. ANSTO is an organisation which commands respect from both sides of the House and from the general public. It has operated the reactor very safely over a long period of time, and has ensured that Australia has been able to take from the reactor the maximum value from the science that was available. Indeed, it has done so in what is now very much a suburban part of Sydney.

However, the issue of the replacement reactor is now before us. The government has taken a firm decision to replace the reactor with a new reactor at Lucas Heights. There is an environmental impact statement now in preparation, and I understand that a report is likely in July or August, with a two-month period for public comment following that and then a final decision based on the environmental impact statement. However, in the interim, the government is certainly of the view that it wants to replace that reactor and build a new reactor at Lucas Heights.

That raises a number of questions. Firstly, there is the issue of cost. The new reactor, as a capital expense, will cost in the order of $300 million. There will be extensive costs over the remaining 50 years of that reactor's life. There will be significant costs for removing and processing the spent fuel rods from the reactor. There will be substantial costs at the end of that 50-year period for decommissioning the reactor, just as there will be significant costs for decommissioning the existing reactor.

So Australia faces a choice. We can spend $300 million, plus who knows how many other tens of millions of dollars over the life of that reactor, or we can consider alternative courses of action. The previous government established the research reactor review just over five years ago, which produced a very extensive report, following a wide ranging public discussion of the subject. That reactor review reached a number of conclusions. Overall, it said that if the government of the day—which is the government we now have—were satisfied that the national interest required a new reactor to be built, then that decision should go ahead, but that it should go ahead only on the basis of the public interest argument.

If you look at the reactor review report closely, you will see that they came to that conclusion not on the basis of medical or scientific evidence but only on the basis of the national interest: in other words, our foreign affairs policy and our ability to participate in nuclear safety debates around the world. If the government felt that those interests were paramount, then it could reasonably reach the view that the reactor should be replaced and a new reactor built. But the research reactor review was not confident that one could come to those conclusions only on the basis of the medical uses of the reactor or only on the basis of the scientific uses of the reactor. It had to be the third factor of national interest that tipped the balance in favour of a new reactor.

Obviously the present government have come to that conclusion, because they have very much endorsed the establishment of the new reactor. So we can assume that they have taken into account the international questions, the national interest and national security and have decided that it is worth proceeding with that expense, based on those criteria. However, those criteria are not public. They are very much a private matter which the government takes into account and keeps its own counsel on. We can only look at the moment at the scientific and medical issues that are before the parliament, and not so much at issues of national security and national interest.

If one looks at the medical question, when Peter McGauran, the former minister, announced in parliament the decision to build the new reactor, he very much took the line that it was the medical question that was paramount. I think that was an unfortunate way to proceed because it certainly generated a strong emotional argument in relation to medical treatment. The reality is that there are many alternative mechanisms for generating radioisotopes, which the minister failed to discuss. He did not bring to our attention the very reasonable alternatives that exist and thereby allow an informed public debate to take place about what is our most substantial science expense to date.

The medical alternatives arise from a number of sources. Firstly, one can reasonably import medical radioisotopes. Some 98 per cent of these are used for diagnostic purposes and only two or three per cent are used for therapeutic purposes. So one can look at alternative diagnostic techniques as well.

In the area of medical radioisotopes, a great many countries import their medical radioisotopes. For example, the United States, the United Kingdom and many countries in Europe import a number of radioisotopes. Countries which we would compare ourselves with also use imported radioisotopes. So that is not out of the question, especially when one considers that, during periods when the research reactor is closed for maintenance, Australia imports substantial quantities of radioisotopes mainly from South Africa but also from Canada and the United Kingdom, and those radioisotopes are able to work very effectively in the Australian medical context.

So that alone is not a compelling argument because we also have available to us cyclotron technology. There is a cyclotron in Sydney and a smaller one in Melbourne, and there are plans to build other units at major hospital facilities around the country. They generate a great many of the radioisotopes which are used in medicine. There is some difficulty at the moment in generating molybdenum which is then allowed to decay into technetium, which is one of the favoured medical radioisotopes. But there are alternative strategies under research at the moment in California which would allow the production of molybdenum and technetium from cyclotron technology and not only from a reactor technology.

There are also medical radioisotopes which are produced by cyclotrons but which are not able to be produced by a reactor. So the issue is not clear cut as far as the medical debate is concerned. I think it is unfortunate that the government opted for the emotive medical argument as its first-run argument rather than allowing a more informed public debate about this to take place so people could make a more rational choice as to whether or not the reactor was necessary.

There is also the question of the scientific and industrial uses of the reactor. For science, reactors are very helpful. There is no doubt that a reactor is useful for the pursuit of some areas of nuclear science. I think ANSTO has done an excellent job in recent years in ensuring that Australia was well represented in those areas. I do not discount the value of that in any way.

Of course, science can be done in a number of ways. There are particle accelerators which use electricity to accelerate particles rather than using the flux of a neutron reactor. There are other mechanisms by which one can undertake studies of materials, for example, spallation sources. Spallation technology is well established. Although that is also expensive and produces some radioactive waste, it is nothing on the scale of a new nuclear reactor. Again even in the scientific area and with the industrial questions of material science, there are a number of alternatives available. They also have not been properly assessed in a wide-ranging public debate.

While the opposition does not per se oppose a new nuclear reactor in this country, it may well be that there are arguments to be made in favour of that. ANSTO is a very creditable and reputable organisation. Their view must be taken with all due weight and significance. Of course, they do have a vested interest in pursuing a new reactor. That obviously is their raison d'etre—the whole reason for the existence of ANSTO—and they would therefore be expected to pursue that argument as strongly as they could in the public arena.

There is also the question of location. The reactor was in an isolated area of Sydney when it was first built, but housing has moved much closer to the reactor and Lucas Heights is now very much a part of suburban Sydney. There is obviously a great deal of disquiet in the area about the prospect of a new reactor and a further 50 years of a nuclear source in the middle of suburban Sydney.

The opposition is very much opposed to the question of building a new reactor in suburban Sydney. While we remain open about the issue of a new reactor in Australia—there are obviously arguments to be had on the science, the industry, the environment, the medical front; all of those things must be properly discussed—we take the view that Lucas Heights is an inappropriate location for this facility. So while we are yet to be convinced by the public argument in relation to the reactor, we do not believe that Lucas Heights is an appropriate venue for it.

The government have failed ANSTO and have failed scientists in this country by not putting the arguments about the need for a new reactor more fairly in the public arena. They have not advanced those arguments in the way that they should have done. They have relied entirely on the emotional impact of the medical question, without ensuring that the public were able to take a more reasoned view. Many scientists support the new reactor but many also question it from the point of view of necessity.

There is the issue of the $300 million initial capital cost. That is a very large amount of money to spend on science and there are many other alternative scientific proposals which could have been funded by that $300 million. No priority analysis appears to have taken place. The government has not set one against the other in the public arena and allowed science and the public to debate which of the alternatives is to be preferred.

The other issue that remains is: where is the $300 million coming from? If one looks at the budget documents presented the other night, one sees that the ANSTO figure is gradually rising. Of course their figure without the reactor is actually suffering a decline, but with the reactor included their funding is rising quite dramatically. The ARC funding—which is a very important source of funding for grants to our young people, to universities, for researchers to undertake further important studies in science—is declining in the forward estimates.

ANSTO strongly put the point of view, which they say is backed by the ARC themselves, that the funding for the reactor has not come from that declining ARC grant. However, on the face of it, on the budget record itself, the government talks about the decline in ARC funding and the figures reflect a very substantial decline. In the absence of any other evidence it is reasonable for scientists and certainly for the opposition to examine the point of view that the government is funding the reactor by a declining grant to ARC.

If that is the case, it will severely impede Australian science in the years ahead and severely disadvantage our young researchers, who already have very little chance of getting an ARC grant. Only about 19 per cent of applicants for ARC grants are successful, and that means some 80 per cent are not. Under the declining allocations listed in the forward estimates, even fewer people will be successful in obtaining those grants. That is a tragedy for our scientists. It is certainly a tragedy for our young scientists, who will increasingly be forced to go offshore.

If this is not the case, if the government in fact has plans to increase ARC funding but they are plans which are not contained in the forward estimates, then the government should make that clear, and they should make it clear immediately. Otherwise, people will draw the conclusion that the declining ARC grant is funding the rising ANSTO grant and that scientists are funding the new reactor from their otherwise expected grants. ANSTO strongly dispute that. I understand that the ARC take a different position, but this is a government which is strongly motivated by the budget dollar.

The Treasurer (Mr Costello) constantly emphasises his ability to effect savings in the Australian government's operation. He constantly emphasises the need for an economic rationalist outcome. While we have had disputes in the parliament between opposition and government about the validity of the Treasurer's strategies, certainly one can understand that the government might well take a decision to reduce one source of funding within a portfolio so that it could increase another. We understand that often ministers are told, `This is a zero sum game. If you want new expenditure, you must come up with savings.' That is a line which the government frequently uses.

Therefore, it is all too easy to draw the conclusion that this has been put to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) and that he has taken a decision to trade off ARC funding against ANSTO funding. If that is not the case, it is up to the minister to come forward quickly in the parliament and in the public arena to dispute that finding; otherwise the opposition and the public will be able to draw that conclusion very reasonably from the budget documents themselves.

In conclusion, while the opposition acknowledges the fine work of ANSTO over the years and accepts that there may well be a role for a research reactor in Australia's future, we believe that that case has not been properly put by the government and that the government has failed to support ANSTO in the way that it should by ensuring that that debate is had on an informed basis.

We certainly believe, though, that Lucas Heights is an inappropriate venue for a nuclear facility, given its location now as part of suburban Sydney. So we want to see a properly informed public debate take place about the need for a reactor as against the other priorities in science and as against the other alternatives in medicine, in industry and in the environmental studies which ANSTO now does. We believe that the government has not taken that view; it has traded off ARC funding against ANSTO funding. We look forward to a more informed public debate on this. I just suspect the government is not going to allow the public that luxury.

talk.start.para: —The object of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 is to protect the health and safety of people, as well as the environment, from the harmful effect of radiation. As an extreme example of the harm radiation poses for our world, I need only refer to the tragedy that was, and still is, Chernobyl. Today, the after-effects of that dreadful event have still not been measured, nor understood in full. Exposure to high levels of radiation results in horrific sickness and destruction of human beings, as well as our environment.

speech.para: In the fast changing world that we live in, the usage of radiation in the home and the workplace is becoming more and more common. It is therefore important that, at all times, the health of our people and our country be protected. This is precisely what this bill will do, especially as the Commonwealth, together with the states and territories, will establish uniform radiation controls. The specific purpose of the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Bill 1998 is to provide a regime to regulate the operation of nuclear installations and the management of radiation sources, including ionising materials and both ionising and non-ionising apparatus, where these activities are undertaken by the Commonwealth.

Radiation can cause severe damage to humans and to the environment, yet radiation is also an invaluable tool in many areas of medicine, archaeology and the construction industry. It is used in the food industry and in scientific research and defence. There are many workers, including those in Commonwealth departments such as Customs and in Australia Post and Telstra, who in carrying out their daily work may come in contact with radiation. Many conflicting views on whether there is a safe level of exposure to ionising radiation have been stated. A report from the OECD notes:

There is a threshold level of radiation exposure (or dose) below which no acute damage is observed. However, there is now a substantial body of evidence which shows that cancers can be caused by radiation even at dose levels that are below this threshold. There is no evidence of inherited damage in humans at any dose level, but the fact that such damage is found to occur in other life forms suggests that it could also occur in humans . . . the assumption that a dose, however small, carries with it an element of risk has become a key concept in radiation protection.
Yet this assertion is not necessarily supported by other reports. The United Nations environment program report Radiation doses, effects, risks states exactly the opposite. It says:

The damage done by high doses of radiation normally becomes evident within hours or days. Cancers, however, take many years—usually decades—to emerge. And, by definition, the hereditary malformations and diseases caused by generic damage take generations to show; it is the children, grandchildren, or remoter descendants of the people originally irradiated who will be affected.

Although there is currently a national standard for limiting occupational exposure to ionising radiation, this bill will allow the Commonwealth to impose licence conditions on Commonwealth employees and contractors dealing with controlled material or operating controlled apparatus.

This is the first time that a body—the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency—will be established in Australia. It will have a function, amongst others, to oversee and regulate activities that involve radiation and nuclear safety and to provide a mechanism where people's complaints can be heard. It is expected that ARPANSA, as I will refer to it from now on, will be set up from 1 July 1998.

This bill is needed to provide a proper legislative basis for the regulation of the nuclear installations and radiation activities of the Commonwealth, none of which are presently regulated. Indeed, it would not be incorrect to say that whilst radiation exposure was covered by state laws, there persisted a regulatory gap because the laws often did not apply to the Commonwealth or its employees, and this was stated in the 1996 report, No time to waste. Thus, the bill will provide the basis for a uniform national approach to regulation of radiation activity and it will be reflected in due course in the legislation of state and territory jurisdictions for the first time.

A major function of the bill will be to allow for the establishment of a statutory officer, a chief executive officer, who will be empowered to make regulations and set licence conditions for the health and safety of persons and for the protection of the environment. It will also be the CEO's function to ensure that all practical steps are taken to avoid conflicts between regulatory, research and service functions.

In establishing certain safety standards, ARPANSA will ensure that Commonwealth users adhere to them by requiring all the radiation sources and nuclear facilities owned by the Commonwealth to be licensed. The organisation will also be empowered to audit performance of Commonwealth operators and users so as to enforce compliance with standards and codes of practice and to impose penalties for significant deficiencies. The ability to impose charges on licences will be introduced at the same time, as will the annual charges for facility licences and for source licences.

ARPANSA will be formed by drawing together the resources and expertise of the Australian Radiation Laboratory and the Nuclear Safety Bureau, both of which are within the Department of Health and Family Services. Currently, ARL provides advice, research and services on the health and medical aspects of radiation, whilst the NSB reviews and monitors the nuclear safety of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation's nuclear operations.

Because of the specialist expertise of ARL and NSB, the amalgamation of these two bodies will provide a strong and uniform regulatory environment in line with international best practice. At the same time, ARPANSA will fill the regulatory gap currently left by dealings involving radioactive material that are not already done by government.

It is also important to note that new functions—such as regulation of a new research reactor, X-ray apparatus used by Customs, and medical and industrial radiography by Defence and other departments—will be fully cost recovered by licence fees. Large organisations will be issued with licences that cover multiple radiation sources and will be required to pay annual licence fees based on the numbers and types of sources. However, the government will continue to provide funding at the present level for the existing functions of both ARL and NSB. Any moneys raised by ARPANSA from charges for the provision of services will be retained by the agency, as currently happens with ARL and NSB, to cover the cost of existing functions.

As I have said already, all Commonwealth bodies that use radiation which may affect the health and wellbeing of the public, employees and the environment will be regulated by ARPANSA. These include research agencies such as the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, the CSIRO, and a variety of radiation users that I have already mentioned. Consultations with these bodies have taken place, and they will continue.

The Commonwealth's radiation protection and nuclear safety activities which need regulatory controls at Commonwealth level include: the operation and decommissioning of ANSTO's nuclear research reactors and the disposal of spent nuclear fuel: the siting, design, commissioning, operation and eventual decommissioning of the proposed replacement research reactor; the Maralinga rehabilitation project; the establishment of a near-surface radioactive waste repository; and the current and future radiation activities of Commonwealth entities, including the use of X-ray equipment and radioactive sources, and the use of non-ionising radiation sources such as lasers, radar and general microwave sources.
