subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 5 March 1998, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the House take note of the paper.

talk.start.para: —Can I say at the outset that I am actually continuing a debate that was brought on very quickly on 5 March of this year. It is ironic when one thinks that the report that we are talking about, the national report into local government which under the 1995 Commonwealth act requires the minister to table it in the House, should have a little bit more debate than what we seem to be doing. It was brought on very quickly at the end of the session when there were only four or five minutes left to debate the issues and now we seem to be having it again at the end of a Main Committee sitting because we have a few moments left over.

speech.para: I believe it is doubly ironic that we have got this report now before us just two days after the Commonwealth has brought down its 1998 budget. Prior to that we had the Australian Local Government Association putting pressure on all representatives right across Australia requesting that they get the message over very clearly to the government about the effects of the cuts that had occurred in the 1997 budget and how that had affected local government.

The 1997 budget cuts totalled $14.7 million and in my state of New South Wales we lost $4,754,758 as a consequence. When you distribute that through local government in New South Wales it adds up to a number of services which local government has had to cut.

I believe when the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in 1997 suspended that agreement there was no formal assurance that the agreement would be reinstated and the funding base restored to an appropriate level for the 1998 budget. That was despite, even then, strong representations to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) by all the premiers of all of the states and territories. In April of this year local government was again asking us as elected representatives at a Commonwealth level to put pressure on both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer to make sure that those grants were restored to their original area of priority.

What we saw then following the budget on Tuesday night was that, even though the local government financial institutions funding was restored, in real terms the fact remained that the 1997 budget had permanently cut the funding base to local government by something like $15 million per year. That has not been restored following the budget on 12 May and what that really means then is that the increase that has come to local government this year of $24 million, which I am sure the government is going to get up and crow about all over Australia, really should have been $39 million.

There should have been a commitment by this government to restore those originally suspended funding cuts to local government. Our urban areas are going to suffer from that because there is going to be continual, ongoing loss to local government and, more importantly I think, regional areas very much are going to be hard hit.

I believe that local government now Australia-wide has certainly put in measures on where they expect funding to go and also what they expect to do in their own areas. But, more importantly, in a report such as this we have the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith), when he tabled the report, saying that the Commonwealth has become a major contributor to the funding of local government and is providing the expertise. We are expecting overviews and we are expecting local government to get their act together. I believe what we should be doing is honouring commitments that have come about in the past and those for the restoration of that funding suspended in 1997.

I can talk more personally of only my own areas that I represent. Not only have we had cuts in financial assistance grants and not only have we had cuts in road funding grants but we have had the absolute abolition of all flood mitigation programs. That has caused a great deal of discontent in areas such as mine. I was very pleased on Saturday when I launched the flood icon that was put together by Fairfield Council and funded by them and the state government of New South Wales. We were able to bring together an education program through the combination of a school—our Fairfield High School students—and local artists and very graphically educate people in the area about flood mitigation.

I bring that up during this local government report because I am very concerned that we have now had not only general cuts not restored in the 1998 budget but we have had no flood mitigation money restored in the 1998 budget. It means areas like mine are going to be grappling with great difficulty in trying to fund what should have been ongoing programs to protect the community I represent. We also have a very difficult problem because flooding does not occur every day of the week and people seem to become immune to the fact that it has not occurred for quite a few years. That is why it was very important that last Saturday we were able to launch a very intensive education program but more importantly an icon that shows very descriptively how the flood levels of our area had been in the 1956, 1986 and 1988 floods.

I might add that in 1988 I had in my local area houses under two and three metres of water and something like 500 people had to be rescued. You do not think that happens in residential areas of an urban part of a local government but, believe me, it does and it has occurred on more than one occasion. That is what I am trying to bring in together. We cannot continue to expect local government to deliver its services while at the same time at a Commonwealth level we do not give them a guarantee of funding. Nor can we expect them to keep programs that are going to better the communities as a whole when we have a stop-start arrangement in regard to how funds are going to be allocated.

In the meantime, I can only say to local government, particularly the areas of Fairfield and Holroyd, to keep up the good work. Let us be assured that we are going to have some sensible application at a Commonwealth level on where local government is going to go in the future not only with the tabling of this report but also I believe from contributions from the Australian Local Government Association as well as local councils across Australia. We need to make sure that this government is kept on its toes and kept informed of the loss to the community and how much it suffers when governments do not meet their commitments.

This report will talk about efficiency in local government for the 1996-97 year. Because the minister is obligated to table reports in the House, it will probably be time to have another report tabled when we still have not finished the debate on the one before us. It is time to reiterate that we did have a commitment on flood mitigation programs, from Commonwealth, state and local government, when that commitment was a two to one ratio. Certainly it was something that all governments at the time were very proud of.

The Howard government abolished that urban flood mitigation program in 1996. I was hoping it would have been reinstated in 1997 and it was not. A certain amount of money was given out when cheques went missing and then came into the throw again for a very few councils in New South Wales. I think the member for Page (Mr Causley) had a small contribution made in 1996 and, because of the outcry of the state government at the time, they realised that they had to at least make contributions to a number of metropolitan councils who were well ahead in the allocation of priorities in that flood mitigation program. My council of Fairfield, in particular, got something like $700,000.

When you make contributions on a two to one basis, for every $2 it is spending the Commonwealth is getting $5 worth of work done in that community and the people overall are gaining from that type of contribution. Yet we have seen that excellent program scrapped. In my area it is going to mean that something like $33 million is still outstanding on flood mitigation works and that is in about today's dollars. Council had a program and an estimate of completing all their flood mitigation works over the next 15 years. That is certainly going to go on a lot further now. They will not be able to meet anywhere near that target.

It worries me because populations change, particularly in urban areas. People move in. We have not had a major flood there since 1988. When people have moved in they have become very blase about it. They say, `It can't happen. It won't affect me.' I can tell you it does affect people. During the last flood, we even had the Hume Highway closed off for something like two or three days. If not for the tremendous effort at local level with the state emergency services, we could have lost lives.

I appeal again to the Commonwealth government that, if you want value in programs, you have to look at involving all levels of government, particularly when you are thinking about the programs that local government becomes very much involved in and becomes very efficient in implementing on the ground. If we look at microeconomic reforms, and at the contribution that local government makes, we have to take that into account.

Another area that also worries me, as far as local government is concerned—and I probably will not have time to bring it up during this debate with the report now being tabled—is where we are going to go with the so-called tax package of the Commonwealth government. Local government has also become very aware that a GST could be on the cards for them. They are going to be suffering enormously if a GST is introduced. Some of the surveys that they have done estimate it is going to cost local government millions and billions of dollars if the type of GST that is being talked about is introduced in this tax package, whenever it sees the light of day.

I would appeal that consideration be given to all of these authorities who are expected to implement certain policies that we direct at a Commonwealth level. They are expected more and more to implement them without the means or the funding with which to do it. As you know, in New South Wales we do have rate pegging. It is something that I have always supported over a long period of time, even though councils object to it and feel that they do not adequately have the means to move their programs around to meet circumstances as they come forward. When one looks at the differentiation between one council and another, and how they move their rates about, perhaps that is something that we have to have in circumstances where better estimation of budgets has to come about.

This report talks about particularly reform. I want to talk about more than just reform. I want commitment. I want commitment given through the Commonwealth through their budget and through the states through their budgets, so that the local authority can implement their programs. We always have that cliche that local governments are closest to the people. I can assure the Commonwealth members that they are. You only have to have your local residents come in at times to complain that the garbage is not picked up or of other things that are happening. People are aware of lack of services but, more importantly, they are aware that the Commonwealth government has reneged on its funding.(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am grateful for the opportunity to finally speak on this report.
—How many times have you rehearsed this speech?
—I do not need to rehearse speeches because I speak from the heart, as the member for Fisher knows, and on behalf of my constituents.
—Order! I would ask the honourable member to direct his remarks through the chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am always prepared to represent my constituents in a sincere and efficient manner without fear or favour, and, for that matter, without the fear of the party whip interfering with me, because I am an Independent. I am grateful for this opportunity.

speech.para: In this report, parliament recognises the legitimate roles of local government in the areas of service delivery and various other functions to which it is suited. These are crucial functions, as the third tier of government in our system—that of local shires and city councils—is essential in the provision of basic services, ranging from waste management through to planning approvals, to health and cultural services, and to roads and infrastructure work. Local government is also important in its complementary function in conjunction with state and federal services. Without healthy, properly representative and accountable local government, our overall system of government is significantly weakened.

This brings me to the state of my own local government authority, the city of Wanneroo. Members in this place will remember that, in the past, I have stood as a strong critic of corruption in the city of Wanneroo. My efforts in part forced the state government to open an inquiry, and later a royal commission, into what was known as Wanneroo Inc. As a result of the inquiries, one-time Liberal mayor Wayne Bradshaw has been imprisoned, and former perjured Liberal state member Wayde Smith is now in jail.

Accusations went deeper, however, and the then Attorney-General and her husband were alleged to have strong links to the group of people that control the Liberal Party in the district that supported and nurtured the control that Mayor Bradshaw had over the city council. They were later cleared of wrongdoing within the terms of the reference of the royal commission.

Although the matters relating to Wanneroo Inc. took place well before the last federal election, its effects continue to be felt. I believe that my stand against corruption in this matter in the northern suburbs, and the subsequent loss of tens of thousands of dollars of illegal fundraising, were an important feature of my not being endorsed as the Liberal candidate for Moore in 1996.

In 1997 and 1998, with the royal commission as a catalyst, the state coalition government decided to suspend all of the democratically elected councillors in Wanneroo and subsequently to split the council into the city of Joondalup and the shire of Wanneroo. The suspension of the councillors beggars belief. The state coalition government actually used the pretence that things had not changed since the days of Bradshaw in order to justify their actions. But the reality is that three former councillors from those days sit on the state government's benches. In other words, three of the people from the days of Wayne Bradshaw's term of office, or from the period when Wayne Bradshaw had strong influence in the city of Wanneroo, now sit on state government benches, deemed to be above suspicion—while councillors who were not even in office during the Wanneroo Inc. days have been suspended.

In fact, the only three councillors who remain from those days and have thus now been punished were in fact whistleblowers. They were people who went to make complaints against what they thought was wrongdoing in the local government authority. What kind of message is that? A cynic could be excused for thinking that they were being punished for blowing the whistle on a very cosy arrangement in the northern suburbs, an arrangement that suited the former mayor, Wayne Bradshaw, very well indeed.

The suspension of councillors allowed the state government to go ahead with its plan to split Wanneroo without serious coordinated opposition from them. The way that it has been done makes it look like a serious misuse of political power by the state government in order to achieve its ends more easily. Whether this is the case is difficult to say: throughout the process, the state government has provided scant detail on why it was necessary to split the city of Wanneroo.

This is made more difficult to understand when one knows that the same state government has made a detailed exploration of amalgamating cities and shires elsewhere, as in the case of Albany in the south-west. Their rationale is to achieve economies of scale that will significantly enhance efficiency and improve services to ratepayers there. The process mirrors a long and substantial process undertaken by the Victorian government. The member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe), who is present today, will of course know about that process, whereby a number of small shires and councils have been amalgamated in order to achieve efficient operations in the third tier of government in that state.

What then is the rationale for splitting Wanneroo, which has achieved a range of efficiencies and economies by virtue of its size and corporate knowledge? Not only can it deliver services at reasonable levels of rates and charges but it also has successfully operated substantial business activity on behalf of its ratepayers, in order to subsidise its services without recourse to significant increases in rates and charges.

The neighbouring city of Stirling, also earmarked for being broken down, commissioned an independent review of the effects of a split. This showed an estimated increase in running costs, owing to losses in economy of scale, of $16 million or 22.78 per cent per year. In the current climate, this will only be offset by increased rates, reduced scope of services to residents, improvements in productivity and increased charges for use of facilities and services.
Importantly, the state government has not indicated what it believes will be the real effect on the residents of Wanneroo—

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—
Sitting suspended from 12.15 p.m. to 12.34 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being past 12.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Main Committee do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —On Monday I am visiting the electorate of McMillan to talk about road funding issues and I would like to make some reference to one particular issue that is of considerable importance in the electorate of McMillan. Before so doing, I would like to make some comments on the context, particularly in the light of the budget of a couple of days ago.

speech.para: National highway funding in Australia in the 1995 budget—the last Labor budget—was $834 million. In last year's budget that went down to $697 million. In the budget two days ago, for 1998-99, it was again slashed, to $675 million. So we have had a drop, within the space of three budgets, from $834 million to $675 million. It is also important to acknowledge that, on the basis of the government's own figures, over four years funding for the national highway maintenance program, which is roughly half of the total, is going to be reduced by half. That will obviously cause severe problems down the track for the national highway in many parts of Australia.

It is also important, as a matter of context, to point out that funding for Victoria as a proportion of total federal road funding has diminished considerably since Labor lost office. Throughout the 1990s when Labor was in office, the average percentage of total federal road funding that went to Victoria was between 20 and 21 per cent. However, that dropped to below 16 per cent last year. That percentage can be contrasted with the 22 per cent of total roadways which are in Victoria and the 25 per cent of total fuel excise receipts which Victoria contributes to the Commonwealth.

The specific matter that I wish to raise today concerns the Pakenham bypass. This is a part of the Princes Highway which I know very well for two reasons. Firstly, having lived in Orbost in my early life, I travelled many times through this particular part of what is now the outer suburbs of Melbourne. Secondly, and more particularly, I know the area well because my mother lives in Berwick and has done so for some time and so I have cause to travel in this area quite a bit now.

The road is one of the heaviest parts of the Princes Highway in terms of traffic. It currently has about 26,000 vehicles per day and it is estimated that by the year 2010 it will have about 37,000 vehicle movements per day. It is one of the critical growth areas of the greater Melbourne area and it currently suffers from a very high accident rate.

On 9 December 1997 the mayor, Councillor Edwin Hume, wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) with respect to the Pakenham bypass, seeking road funding for that project, and I have a copy of the letter here with me today. I should add that Councillor Hume is the Mayor of the Cardinia Shire which has the greatest interest in this bypass proposal. Unfortunately, it took the Prime Minister four months to organise any response to his letter. Finally, on 3 April this year his parliamentary secretary, the member for Braddon (Mr Miles), wrote back stating amongst other things `the delay in replying is regretted' and stating that the Pakenham bypass is a Victorian government responsibility.

It is interesting to note that the government was refusing to provide any roads of national importance funding for the Pakenham bypass yet it seems able to provide roads of national importance funding—it has announced that it will—for Main Road 92 in New South Wales in the marginal coalition electorate of Gilmore, and parts of that road currently are gravel.

We have therefore a situation where the government seems unable to provide roads of national importance funding for a road which currently has 26,000 cars and trucks per day, and it is anticipated that within barely a decade it will have 37,000 vehicles a day, but it can provide funding for a relatively minor road, parts of which are only gravel at the moment, because it happens to be in an electorate where the Prime Minister obviously wants to assist the cause of the incumbent member.

What does this tell us about the member for McMillan (Mr Broadbent)? Obviously, he is not a very good lobbyist for his electorate. Obviously, he does not have the ear of the Prime Minister. He does not have the ability to get the Prime Minister to respond to the needs of his electorate. He could not get an answer out of the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister took four months to even respond to the correspondence. And whereas the Prime Minister is prepared to provide funding for a relatively minor road in the electorate of Gilmore, he seems unable to do that for the member for McMillan in what is obviously a very important case, the Pakenham bypass.

talk.start.para: —I suppose one legacy that all of us would like to leave our electorates, apropos of the comments of the previous speaker, is better transport infrastructure. I would like to very much see better transport infrastructure on the Warringah peninsula.

speech.para: People have been talking about this issue for more than 100 years. In the 1870s there was talk of a railway to Narrabeen. Dr Bradfield, the builder of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, proposed a railway to the northern beaches. In the 1970s the Warringah Expressway began construction and, as you know, it does not go anywhere near Warringah; it ends up at Gore Hill. In the early 1990s a section 22 planning committee was established by the former coalition state government but it was wound up by the present Labor state government before it had a chance to complete its work.

After 100 years of procrastination, what the peninsula needs is six months of decision making and then three years of construction to give the people of Warringah the transport infrastructure they need. But what in fact are we getting? From the current state Labor government—absolutely nothing.

Late last year, I wrote to Premier Carr asking that some consideration be giving to using Sydney Water's impending infrastructure tunnel for a transport right of way. In part, I received a response from the state transport minister, Carl Scully, who pointed out that there were no major transport initiatives intended in that part of Sydney in the medium future. Worse, he said that the state government was considering putting a transit lane on Warringah Road. He wrote:
Provision of a transit lane on Warringah Road is being considered as part of this program to further enhance public transport usage.

Tens of thousands of people use Warringah Road every morning and every night in the peak hours. It is already, according to the NRMA, massively congested along the whole of its length. It is on some mornings one of the world's longest parking lots and this proposal from the state government is just going to make things massively worse. Tens of thousands of Warringah residents use this road and what is going to happen under this state government proposal is that the existing three lanes of traffic will be forced to merge into two lanes of traffic. What will happen is that tens of thousands of commuters will have 10, 20, 30 minutes a day added to their daily journeys. As they are sitting there in their traffic jams, they will have one person to thank and that is Bob Carr—and he should be appropriately rewarded, if this insanity goes ahead, at the next election.

It is absolutely wrong for the state government to attempt to avoid its responsibility to provide decent transport infrastructure in Warringah by turning car commuters against bus commuters. This pathetic `divide and rule' strategy simply cannot be allowed. What the Warringah peninsula desperately needs is greater transport infrastructure because that will enable both public and private transport to proceed better in an important part of Sydney.

I call on the state government to immediately repudiate Carl Scully's comments that a transit lane is being considered for Warringah Road and I also call on the state government to immediately reconvene the section 22 planning committee so that these issues can be considered and decided and acted upon.

talk.start.para: —I would like to speak in this adjournment debate about the issue of child care. I think this is an important issue that the federal government seems to have forgotten. The economic facts of life for many young families, particularly low and medium income families, is that if they are to own their own family home there is a need for two incomes to assist in paying off the mortgage.

speech.para: The McMahon government introduced government financial support for child care in the 1970s. Economic requirements, plus the desire of many married women to retain their employment skills to enable them to continue with their careers, have meant that the demand for community and council run child-care centres has increased considerably since that time. Parents with children in before and after school child care, and I quote directly from a circular sent from one child-care centre in my electorate, are being told:

In short, we are losing all our funding. Our only income will be through the collection of fees and fundraising. As a result, our fees will be increased dramatically. This centre has not had a fee increase for at least five years so the increase might come as a shock to some parents.

But in the same circular parents are being advised that the income that the federal government saves by not funding centres is to be allocated to fee relief for eligible families. However, this is not happening. Operators advised me that only a small number of families have registered with Centrelink for fee relief. Figures quoted are that only 18,000 out of an expected 70,000 have registered. This shortfall is causing concern, with serious problems expected during the school year as more children fall into risk due to inadequate care and supervision before and after school.
In its submission to the Senate inquiry on child care, the New South Wales government said, on pages 23 and 24 of their submission:
It is well recognised that women still maintain the primary responsibility for care given in the family, often caring for both children and older family members.

These women are more likely than men to reduce or leave paid employment in order to fulfil these responsibilities. The primary carer's inability to participate in paid employment may add financial pressure to other pressures experienced by carers.

The facts are that, due to government policy, child care has become too expensive for many ordinary families. This has meant that women's ability to remain in the work force has been jeopardised, and the ability of sole parents to get off the pension and their children to access quality child care have all been threatened. A number of community based before and after school centres in my electorate, such as Seven Hills West and Blacktown North, are struggling to survive. Operational subsidies for care of school-aged children and block grants to vocational care were abolished in the federal government's budget of 1997. These decisions came into effect in April this year and amount to a loss of over $10 million in New South Wales.

Many families are unable to pay the increased fees brought on by the removal of the operational subsidies. Some examples of the fees increases are that Blacktown North fees have increased by $20 to $70 a week and daily after school care rates have increased by 25 per cent to $15. Daily morning care and after school care fees have increased by $5 to $8 and $8.50 respectively, while recreational care has doubled from $10 to $20 a day.

Many centre operators are saying everything is basically on trial for the next three months. If they lose too many children, they will have to cut staff. All families will be paying different amounts depending on their income. In many cases, it is a choice for parents of whether to pay the mortgage or send their children to child care.

One of the biggest problems facing the centres is the enormous amount of paperwork administration connected with the government's new procedures. In talking to operators of community based before and after school care centres, I am told many parents are dropping out of child care because of an increase in fees. On the other hand, they are also pulling out because of confusion over how the government's new funding arrangements work.

One long day child-care centre in my electorate that I previously mentioned in this House is the Lalor Park centre. This centre previously had 60 children in it. The centre was unable to operate efficiently with the removal of the operational subsidy and closed its doors at Christmas. The Blacktown Council, to its credit, intended to reopen this centre but, due to increased fees, only a handful of children have enrolled. This is a clear indication that the Howard government's economic policy is placing child care out of the reach of ordinary Australian families. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last night, in the House, I paid tribute to a very special group of people, the recipients of the 1998 Forde Community Contribution Awards. I established these awards as a way for the local community to say thankyou to these very special people who work quietly and tirelessly in many voluntary organisations. These are people who give our community its heart and soul. They never seek recognition for their efforts. They are modest, dedicated people who believe in helping others. They make our local area a better place to live because of their hard work. This year I was pleased to be able to recognise 28 local residents in a very small way and to say thankyou wholeheartedly to them from a very grateful community.

speech.para: Last night, I paid tribute to 20 of the Beaudesert Shire recipients. Time ran out, so I am back here today to seek recognition for the other eight people in our Beenleigh recipients awards. They include David Bennett for his many hours of work with the Beenleigh and District Rugby Union Club, and also his recent efforts, along with his wife Sandy, to establish the Eagleby Redbacks and help provide supporting services for young people.

I would also like to pay tribute to Eve Harling who was nominated for her tireless efforts with the Kiah Club at Mount Tamborine. This very special lady, for the last 20 years, has supplied morning and afternoon teas and birthday cakes to our local elderly. The person who nominated her said she has never let them down.

Diane Michels has been a district leader of the Girl Guides Association and is always willing to lend a hand. The person who nominated her said she is always available, leading and teaching them by example. She is a great role model for our young people.

Merv Musch was nominated for his long and tireless work as a member of the Lions Club. Merv never missed a meeting for 27 years. He had 100 per cent attendance. I think that shows sheer dedication to any service group.

Arthur and Ivy Somerfield were nominated for their many years of service to Beenleigh Red Cross and especially for their work at the Medical Loan Centre. They have also worked very hard with their local Meals on Wheels.
Mark Tully was also nominated for his hard work in helping establish Studio Village Community Centre and for his strong community work within the village and Helensvale communities.
Marion Willmann is another great worker for the Beenleigh Red Cross and Meals on Wheels, and she has also given a great deal of time to help others.

This year for the first time we had a very special award for an extremely dedicated local community group, the Beenleigh Senior Citizens Entertainment Group. Today I also recognise their tremendous work. This dedicated group—the oldest member is 98 and she can do the cancan on stage like no-one I have ever seen before—puts on shows for local residents in nursing homes. Most of the people in these nursing homes are younger than the entertainers on the stage, and so it is absolutely wonderful to see them work. Their songs bring great memories back to the old people and joy to all who hear them perform.

They are a lively, generous group of people who bring a smile to the faces of so many of our local elderly. I would like to quickly run through their names and thank them: Edith Brown, Barbara Bullis, Win Burton, Rozalie Charters, Kevin Charters, Allen and Irene Cook, Beryl Davies, Marjorie Fels, Don and Doreen Fraser, Merle Golinski, Wal Henderson, Robert Herse, Gordon Herse, Len Holmes, Bill Howden, Ken Jones, Maisie Karppinen, Monty and Fuchsia Kerkin, Margaret Leadbetter, Les Leibinger, Laurie Loveless, Ivy Lubach, Ruth Mahoney, Ruth Rasmussen, Bernice Robertson, Wilf and Pearl Simmonds, Mike Smith, Larry Storey, Sheila Talary, Pat Thurlow, Royce Watt, Ray Watt, Bob Wild, Alan Wilke, Elvina Wiltshire, Esther Wyatt, Albert and Jean Yates, and Joyce Zipf.

I am sure all honourable members will join me in recognising and congratulating the members of the Beenleigh Senior Citizens Entertainment Group, as well as the very special 28 local individual recipients. I am pleased to be able to stand here today in parliament and thank them all once again. I believe that their sense of community spirit helps enrich and brighten the lives of many others. The community is very grateful for their work, and I am honoured to be able to represent these very special people.

talk.start.para: —I use this opportunity to call on the Commonwealth government again to have a very close look at an extraordinary act of environmental vandalism which the Victorian government is presently involved in. This vandalism in my electorate involves the Minister for Planning issuing a directive to the Moonee Valley City Council to grant a planning permit with respect to the filling of a quarry hole with contaminated and toxic wastes. The particular quarry hole is in a residential area. It is cheek by jowl with a very substantial number of residential properties in the suburbs of Niddrie and East Keilor. It is an area which is very heavily populated, with schools in close proximity to the site.

speech.para: It beggars description as to how the Minister for Planning in Victoria has come to the extraordinary decision of directing the local council to issue a permit. He further compounds his environmental vandalism by providing—in the planning arrangements that he is dictating to the council—access to the site through a park, a very well established and delightful little park that runs alongside a creek. This park is going to be converted, if the minister has his way, into an access way for large numbers of trucks rumbling through a residential area and depositing toxic wastes for the next 10 years.

There are issues here that the Commonwealth ought to look at very closely. I believe that there are issues in relation to the proximity of this site, which will involve substantial amounts of earth movements, to the flight paths into both Melbourne airport and Essendon airport. I believe that there is an imperative need for the Commonwealth to look very carefully afresh at this proposal, in order to ensure that this project does not create problems for aviation by any association of the area with birds. There are also very important issues in relation to leeching of contaminated wastes out of the site into the Maribyrnong River, which is not very far away, and ultimately into Port Phillip Bay.

The Minister for the Environment and others in the government have made great play in recent times about the natural heritage fund and the role the Commonwealth is now claiming to play in relation to environmentally upgrading waterways in coastal areas. Yet we have the Victorian government directing that a proposal proceed that undoubtedly will lead to the contamination of the Maribyrnong River and, ultimately, Port Phillip Bay.

Further, there are areas in Port Phillip Bay that are covered by the Ramsar agreement to which Australia is a party. The Ramsar agreement is an international agreement that relates to the protection of wetlands that are important to migratory birds. There are certainly areas in Port Phillip Bay which, I would suggest, may well be affected by contaminated materials coming ultimately from this site, and this provides a basis for the Commonwealth to act.

It seems extraordinary to me that, while the Commonwealth is paying some attention to coastal areas and to waterways, and, presumably, the Victorian government has its hand up for some money for those sorts of activities, the Victorian minister is making directions that this outrageous proposal proceed.

I urge the Minister for the Environment to look very closely at this matter. He was kind enough last night to meet with me and the member for Lalor (Mr Jones), who faces a comparable issue in his electorate of Lalor, and I hope that the minister, as a consequence of the representations we have made to him, will be prepared to act in terms of the Commonwealth's interests in these matters, and in ways that protect the residents of the western suburbs of Melbourne.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to reply to the comments made by the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) in the House last sitting session.

speech.para: It was the most extraordinary, vicious and personal attack I have ever heard on one of the members in this place, and the person so vehemently attacked was none other than the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), the leader of our country. The member believes that because the Prime Minister wore shorts and long white socks during the 1960s; did not drive a tie-dyed kombi van; was not out there demonstrating against the Vietnam war; or listening to the Doors, that somehow this decreases his ability to lead the country.

The member's comments obviously demonstrate that he missed the very essence of what the flower power children of the 1960s were trying to convey. Much of their sentiment and the movement of the 1960s was a backlash against people being judged and excluded on the basis of gender, disabilities, religion, age, race, economic status and, yes, appearance. Perhaps the member is a little bitter and envious because he missed the era of the flower power children.

As the member for Grayndler is a self-proclaimed socialist democrat, I am surprised that he has not paid much attention to South Australian political history. A certain former premier of socialist leaning, the former member for Norwood, Don Dunstan, often wore long white socks and shorts—pink, for that matter—in the parliament of South Australia. I would be very interested to hear what the member for Grayndler would have to say in relation to one of his mentors wearing white socks, pink shorts and/or safari suits, notwithstanding, of course, that this was the accepted trendy fashion dress of the times.

In fact, my father and many others of that generation wore long white socks and shorts during those years. My father by that time was busily establishing his Volkswagen repair business to provide for his young family and was more concerned to provide food and housing for his wife and children than running off in a tie-dyed kombi van because others thought he should. Although as a Volkswagen mechanic one of his jobs was to repair kombi vans, we never spied a tie-dyed one—maybe that is a New South Wales thing. Many flower power people, hippies, drop-outs and the movers and the shakers during the 1960s drove other cars, I am sure, apart from tie-dyed kombis.

Music was not restricted just to the Doors. We were listening to Credence Clearwater Revival, the Beach Boys, Tiny Tim, Normie Rowe, the Beatles, Deep Purple, Rolling Stones and Janis Joplin. Yes, my family did attend church functions on Saturday nights and church on Sunday mornings. It has been well documented through anecdotal and researched evidence that the 1960s was an era of unprecedented illicit drug abuse and other such activities, perhaps even by some who did drive tie-dyed kombi vans during that era. I am very pleased and proud that my father, along with John Howard and millions of other Australians, continued to work in a responsible and dependable manner—after all, in my father's case, someone had to keep the kombis on the road.

As I stated in my first speech, although my father has been in business for more than 40 years, at 67 he still works every day in his garage and washes his hands with Solvol, as I often did, probably more times than have all of those who sit on the opposite side of the House. I must ask the member for Grayndler: does he believe that only people in their late 20s during the 1960s, who drove around stoned in tie-dyed kombi vans, are fit for leadership at this present time? Is this his vision for what an Australian leader should be?

The vision and leadership of John Howard as the Prime Minister of Australia is clear: solid fiscal and economic management to lead Australia into the 21st century; a stable and secure economy for the benefit of all Australians in an increasingly unstable economic outlook for our near neighbours; establishment of a culture of mutual obligation at not only a familial and community level but also at a societal level; promotion of the wellbeing of families and the nurture of our children; combating the increasing level of illicit drug use in our society, to protect our children as much as possible from the ravages of drug abuse—surely a commendable vision; and provision of a sustainable, workable aged care system for our ageing population into and beyond the 21st century, as well as a sustainable and workable child-care system.

While the Prime Minister has been criticised for having old-fashioned Christian values, as I see it, there is nothing wrong with caring for the family values and Christian ethics. Australia could do with some more, which is an improvement, may I say, on the stoned, tie-dyed kombi van driver of the sixties.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak on the benefits that the government has provided in the budget, particularly regarding veterans. I say this in light of an article that appeared in my local newspaper today, The Daily News , which states:

speech.para: Wealthy war vets `only ones better off' after Budget.

The article particularly focuses on the comments by a Tweed Heads legal advocate, Mr Rob Martin, who said that this budget has a `slash and burn' approach to the welfare of veterans. He goes on to say that the government is `wrong, wrong, wrong' to suggest that veterans will be better off.

Let me put the record straight. The total budget for the veterans' affairs portfolio for 1998-99 is $7.25 billion, the largest ever. It represents over a 7.4 per cent increase, or around $500 million. This will be particularly relevant to the electorate of Richmond where we have one of the highest aged populations, with over 24,000 people over the age of 65. Indeed, around 7,500 individuals receive a veterans' affairs pension. The announcement made last night regarding extending the gold card, which is clearly to World War II veterans who served abroad, will benefit about 840 veterans in the electorate of Richmond. They will be significantly better off than they were prior to the budget announcement.

It is particularly important for Mr Martin to recognise that $150 million of the budget of the veterans' affairs portfolio is being spent—over 600 over four years—to purchase, directly, hospital services for veterans. This is in addition to $194 million to cover health services, which reflects the increased health needs of our ageing veterans.

Those veterans who did not serve abroad, and who are self-funded retirees, will also benefit through the announcement made last night that the Commonwealth seniors health card will be made available to self-funded retirees on an income of up to $67,000 for a couple, and around $40,000 for a single. This is significant because it gives them access to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and it gives them back the equivalent benefits that many pensioners receive. This is significant for the veterans community and for those individuals who did not see active service outside the country, particularly in World War II.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney Opera House World Heritage Listing
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2409)

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 23 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Has a Prime Minister of Australia written to a Premier of New South Wales concerning the nomination of the Sydney Opera House for inscription on the World Heritage list; if so, when.
(2) Has a Premier of New South Wales written to a Prime Minister of Australia concerning such a nomination; if so, when.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Prime Minister wrote to the Premier of New South Wales, the Hon Bob Carr MP, on 19 August 1996 concerning nomination of the Sydney Opera House in its Harbour Setting for inscription on the World Heritage List.

(2) The Premier of New South Wales wrote to the Prime Minister on the same topic on 24 October 1996 and 27 March 1997. The then Acting Premier, the Hon Andrew Refshauge MLA, also wrote to the Prime Minister on the topic on 25 July 1996.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Are advance payments to recipients of social security benefits to be restricted to one per year; if so, why.
(2) Is it possible for recipients to defraud the existing advance payment system; if so, how.
(3) Will the Minister review the justification for changing the advance payment scheme.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Advance payments to recipients of social security benefits were restricted to one per year from 1 January 1997. This reflected community and welfare group concerns that customers who re ceived more than one advance per year were placed in unnecessary financial hardship and also resulted in an unsustainable increase in pressure on welfare services provided by these groups.

(2) The advance payments scheme is simply a lump sum payment of a customer's future entitlement of income support. The Department of Social Security (DSS) is aware that fraud can occur in respect of a small number of income support customers. However, there are various measures in place in order for fraud to be detected and minimised. For example, when a customer is granted a payment, Centrelink records are checked to identify whether the customer has any outstanding debts resulting from a previous period on an income support payment. Centrelink customer data is matched with Australian Taxation Office Employment Declaration form data to identify customers who have failed to notify that they have commenced or recommenced employment.
(3) The Department is currently in the process of conducting a broad review of the advance payment scheme in order to identify areas of improvement.

subdebateinfo.title: Visa Requirements: Peoples Republic of China
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2665)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Has the Government eased the visa requirements for the citizens of the Peoples Republic of China (PRC).
(2) Is it a fact that PRC citizens have the fifth highest incidence of overstaying visas.

(3) What strategies will his Department adopt to (a) monitor visa applications for possible overstayers and illegal immigrants, (b) ensure there is not a sharp increase in onshore refugee applications from PRC citizens, (c) have effective systems to police and expel overstayers and (d) have appropriate protocols with the PRC to ensure that it can speedily and effectively accept its citizens expelled from Australia for breaking visa requirements.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. There has been no easing of the visa requirements for the citizens of the Peoples Republic of China.

The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) has located a Principal Migration Officer (Compliance) in Beijing to assist the Migration Officers stationed in China in visa fraud detection and prevention. Comprehensive local profiles are used to assist officers detect fraud in applications across the range of visas. Claims made in these visa applications are checked, if necessary with third parties such as employers, for accuracy and credibility.

The performance of travel agents in China involved with travel to Australia is monitored to identify those who have been associated with applications for visas where it has consistently been found that there was an intent not to comply with the provisions of the visas issued.
Immigration staff in Beijing closely monitor Chinese business and family visitors to ensure compliance with their visa conditions. Strategies include:
. regular requests for database checks in Australia to see if persons granted visas have returned to China;

. the maintenance of databases by the Australian Embassy in Beijing to identify likely organisers of fraudulent entry schemes as well as companies, both Chinese and Australian, with a history of involvement in visa scams;
. ongoing liaison and exchange of information concerning visa fraud with visa officers of other embassies; and
. regular training of embassy and airline staff on Australia's visa and documentation requirements.

Applicants for student visas are subject to the stringent bona fides criteria which are applied to student visa applicants from all non-gazetted countries. In addition, the following criteria (first introduced in November 1992 and amended in July 1994) must be met by students from the PRC:

. English language comprehension of a minimum proficiency level of 570 in the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) or equivalent. This does not apply to primary and secondary students (other than direct enrolments into Year 12).
. Post-secondary qualifications will only be accepted from selected "known institutions".
The additional criteria do not apply to:
. government sponsored students;
. secondary exchange students;
. students enrolling in a primary school course or secondary school course (except direct enrolments into year 12); or
. students enrolling to undertake postgraduate studies, ie, a course of study or research leading to a masters degree or doctorate; or
. any dependants.

While these additional measures are generally applied to all non-exempt citizens of the PRC, since July 1996, the Chief Migration Officer in Beijing has had the discretion to waive the TOEFL requirement for full-fee paying private students applying for a student visa to undertake a degree course in Australia where the student has:
(a) successfully completed in the PRC an associate diploma course (or above) which has been conducted in English by Australian teachers employed by an Australian education provider;

(b) provided evidence from the Australian education provider that they have achieved the required level of English to enable them to successfully undertake the proposed degree course in Australia; and
(c) applied for the visa within 12 months of having achieved the required level of English.

As you will be aware, my Department is currently in the process of finalising a Review of the Student Visa Program. Many of the submissions that were received made reference to the situation of private students from the PRC and the special entry requirements that were put in place in response to concerns over their high level of overstay and non-compliance with visa conditions. These additional policy requirements have been closely examined by the review team and I will be addressing the relevant recommendations in my response to the Review, which will be completed shortly.
(2) Yes, this fact is published in the Department's `Fact Sheet' Series, in Fact Sheet 80, entitled `Locating Overstayers in Australia'.
(3) (a) In addition to the safeguards inherent in a universal visa system there are other initiatives in place to counter visa fraud:
. Principal Migration Officers (Compliance) are posted to overseas locations of concern to closely scrutinise applications for visas;
. Airport Liaison Officers are working in overseas airports checking the bona fides and documentation of travellers to Australia;

. The Border Control and Compliance Division was established in my Department in November 1997 to focus on maximising efforts to deal with fraud against the Migration Act 1958. Within the Division there is an area with specific responsibility for developing strategies to counter attempts to circumvent Australia's border controls.

(b) Australia's obligations under the Refugee Convention mean that any non-citizen in Australia is able to make an application for a Protection Visa, and have that application properly assessed. The streamlined onshore protection decision making that resulted from the administrative and legislative changes introduced by the Coalition Government allowed the Department to identify quickly those Protection Visa applicants with genuine claims and to remove the benefit of a prolonged stay from non-bona fide applicants. Top priority is given to applicants in detention, victims of torture and trauma and those in receipt of Asylum Seekers Assistance (ASA).

Legislative changes were introduced in July 1997 limiting the provision of work rights to protection visa applicants who have been in Australia for less than 45 days in the past 12 months. This has the effect of discouraging frivolous applications from people who have been in Australia for a significant period of time and who wish to further extend their stay.

In addition, a new $1000 post-decision fee for Refugee Review Tribunal (RRT) applicants who have been determined as not to be refugees was introduced. This fee was designed to deter non-bona fide applicants from seeking review by the RRT after receiving a negative primary decision from the Department.

(c) Under provisions of the Migration Act 1958 (the Act), any person who is an unlawful non-citizen must be detained. Improving technology and data matching increases DIMA's ability to detect unlawful non-citizens.

Section 189 of the Act requires all non-citizens to be detained unless they are the holder of a visa. Bridging visas are available to eligible non-citizens (see section 72) to ensure persons can maintain lawful status while they await the outcome of a decision on their immigration status or to depart Australia within a specified period. Unless a bridging visa is granted, unlawful non-citizens are liable to mandatory detention under Section 189 of the Act and to removal, as soon as practicable, under Section 198.

Community information has been a prime source of information on overstayers until very recently—some 750 were found this way in 1996-97. The increasing use of data-matching technology is likely to overtake this:

. all passengers arriving in and departing from Australia complete a card giving their personal and travel details. By checking one against the other, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs locates the names of overstayers;

. those names are then matched against lists of people receiving benefits or paying tax to find a last-known address. The result is then double-checked, to ensure the person has not since applied for a further visa or left Australia. Immigration officials then follow up and locate the overstayers.
Overstayers are subject to an exclusion period from returning to Australia, usually up to three years, irrespective of whether they leave voluntarily.

Former overstayers cannot be given visas to return to Australia even after the exclusion period has finished until they repay the cost of their removal and detention and any post-decision fee to the RRT.

(d) The PRC, like all sovereign states, accepts the obligation of receiving back its nationals and does so willingly. A formal protocol or agreement has not proved to be necessary. Difficulties do arise in determining the nationality and identity of certain individuals and this can cause delays in repatriation to their home countries. This occurs, particularly in cases where the individuals provide deliberately misleading information or refuse to cooperate in order to frustrate their removal from Australia. However, this applies to nationals of many countries.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) What role is his Department playing in ensuring that Australia does not continue to be a destination in the trade of females for sexual exploitation.
(2) Has his Department cooperated with the Attorney-General's Department on the matter; if so, how.
(3) Has he asked his Department to identify the major sources of the so-called sex slavery trade in Australia.
(4) Is he able to say what are the sources and what numbers are involved.
(5) Is he further able to say how the sources have changed since 1989.

(6) Has his Department been able to develop a profile of the traffickers in the source countries who recruit, organise and profit from prostitution; if so, have the profiles been correlated to detect incidences between traffickers and promoters or sellers of so called $30 work visas.

(7) Has it been established whether Australian citizens are actively involved in the sex slave trade; if not, what action has been taken to prevent traffickers from entering Australia to exploit their victims.
(8) Has his Department identified the category of visas by which the females are entering Australia.
(9) What steps is his Department taking to eliminate deficiencies in the issuing of visas.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) My Department views the illegal entry for prostitution as an ongoing concern having wider law enforcement, community health and welfare and social justice ramifications.
My Department works closely with law enforcement and other relevant agencies on matters relating to abuse of the visa system to enable women to enter Australia to work in the sex
industry. Immigration officers stationed overseas assist with the investigation of illegal entry rackets and the identification of individuals involved.

(2) My Department has contributed to the preparation of a discussion paper on a proposal to deal with the problem. The discussion paper was referred to the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG) which considered it in late December 1997. SCAG has referred the matter to the Model Criminal Code Officers Committee (MCCOC) for examination. The MCCOC is due to report back to the SCAG Officers meeting in April 1998.
(3) The predominant non-citizens working illegally in the sex industry in Australia are Thai nationals.
(4) The following table shows the nationality and number of non-citizens located working illegally in brothels 1996-97:

(5) During the 1990s Thai nationals have dominated the non-citizens who have been located working in the sex industry in breach of their visa conditions. This is a change from the late 1980s when nationals of the Philippines and Malaysia were more numerous.

(6) It has not been possible to develop a profile of the traffickers in the source countries who recruit, organise and profit from prostitution. To date, the non-citizen women located working in the sex industry in Australia, have been reluctant to provide any information which might assist in the identification of recruiters and organisers. However, combating fraud is a high priority for my Department which:
. views the entry of women to work illegally in the sex industry as an ongoing concern having wider law enforcement, community health and welfare and social justice ramifications; and
. is trying to engender increased cooperation between sending and receiving countries to deal with people trafficking in all its forms—including women working illegally in the sex industry.

(7) Please refer to the answer to question (6) above. My Department, however, works closely with law enforcement and other relevant agencies on matters relating to the trafficking of women to Australia to work in the sex industry.

(8) The majority of women located working in the sex industry in breach of the conditions of their visas have entered Australia on visitors visas, often obtained by false representations and/or the use of bogus or fraudulently obtained documentation.
(9) My Department's visa issuing process is a success. In addition to the safeguards inherent in a universal visa system there are other initiatives in place to counter visa fraud:
. Principal Migration Officers (Compliance) are posted to locations of concern overseas to closely scrutinise applications for visas;
. Airport Liaison Officers are working in overseas airports checking the bona fides and documentation of travellers to Australia;

. The Border Control and Compliance Division was established in November 1997 to focus on maximising efforts to deal with fraud against the Migration Act 1958. Within the Division there is an area with specific responsibility for developing strategies to counter attempts to circumvent Australia's border controls.

subdebateinfo.title: Defence Service Homes: Interest Rate Reductions
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2696)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Did he undertake on 3 September 1997 to reduce mortgage rates for Defence Service Homes (DSH) loans with effect from 5 January 1998.
(2) Has his Department advised DSH borrowers that Westpac is unable to effect reductions in DSH loan repayments until late March 1998; if so, what are Westpac's reasons for the delay.
(3) What is the estimated additional cost of providing DSH loan borrowers with an interest rebate backdated to 3 September 1997 instead of 5 January 1998.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. On 3 September 1997, I announced that the interest rates on most Defence Service Home (DSH) loans would drop to around 5.6 per cent, given the prevailing market interest rates at the time. These changes were to become effective from 5 January 1998. In fact, the monthly variable maximum DSH rate has dropped even lower, to a level of 5.24 per cent, effective from 5 January 1998. This is because average market rates have fallen from 7.13 per cent since my announcement in September 1997 to their current level of 6.74 per cent. The new arrangements guarantee a Commonwealth interest subsidy of 1.5 percentage points, leaving DSH borrowers with that discount off the prevailing market rate.

(2) Some DSH loans attract capped interest rates of 3.75 per cent and 4.5 per cent. These loans are already lower than the monthly variable discounted rate of 5.24 per cent. Where this is the case, the lower rate applies. Those loans would not be affected by the 1.5 per cent subsidy guarantee unless average market rates fell below 5.25 per cent or 6 per cent respectively. The current level of subsidy up to the market rate on these loans is already greater than 1.5 per cent.

In mid-December 1997, my Department and Westpac jointly wrote to all existing DSH borrowers, informing them that while the interest rate reduction would take effect from 5 January 1998, systems changes would need to be phased in between January and March 1998. The brochure enclosed with each letter also explained that any changes in repayment arrangements would be advised at a later stage. A hotline was established to answer any borrower queries. My Department advised telephone callers that they could approach the Bank in late March 1998 to inquire about reducing their repayments if that was their wish.

This measure, to reduce the interest rates on DSH loans while market rates are low, represents a major shift away from the fixed rates concept which has applied since the scheme's inception in March 1919. The rates are now capped at the previous fixed effective rates, but are reduced to a rate 1.5 per cent below the average variable home loan rates applied to the largest number of owner-occupied housing loans of the five major banks each month, if the capped rate exceeds that rate. These arrangements will ensure that DSH interest rates will always be significantly lower than market rates, however far these may fall, in recognition of the nation's debt to the veteran community.

In order to implement this change, considerable systems development work was necessary, both for my Department and Westpac. The bulk of that work, which commenced around the time of my announcement in September 1997, is now complete. Interest rebates covering the period 5 January to 4 March 1998 inclusive were credited to relevant accounts on 18 March 1998. Delaying reductions in loan repayments until after that phase of the task had been completed will make for a more orderly approach to dealing with individual requests.
The changes to interest rates could not commence before the legislation was amended by Parliament. Three months lead time on top of the legislative timing is in accord with normal banking practice.
(3) The estimated additional cost of providing DSH borrowers with an interest rebate backdated to 3 September 1997 instead of 5 January 1998 would be in the order of $5.36m.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) What is Australia's position on the (a) existence and continued expansion of Israeli settlements in the Palestinian and Arab territories occupied by Israel since 1967 and (b) consistency of Israeli settlement activity in the occupied territories with the letter and spirit of the Oslo Agreements, the Hebron Protocol and all relevant UN resolutions.

(2) Is he able to say whether Australian citizens, organisations or companies provide funding to support activities in the occupied territories which threaten to impede further progress in the Middle East peace process; if so, what is the Government's position.

(3) What are Australia's responsibilities and obligations to prevent financial assistance being provided by Australian citizens, organisations or companies to support Israeli settlement activities in the occupied territories.
(4) What action has the Government taken on the matter.
(5) Is he able to say whether the use of tax-exempt funds from Australia to assist Israeli institutions or settler groups in the occupied territories is prohibited under Australian law.

(6) Do his Department, the Australian Taxation Office or other Government bodies monitor the sending of tax-exempt funds from Australia to support groups or institutions whose presence or activities in a particular region are contrary to international law or UN resolutions; if so, by what mechanism.
(7) Is he able to say what sums are being sent from Australia to support political organisations based in the occupied territories and to which organisations they are being sent.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Australia considers Israeli settlement activity in those territories occupied by Israel in 1967 to be harmful to the peace process.

(b) The Interim Agreement between Israel and the Palestinian Authority requires that neither side change the status of the West Bank and Gaza pending the outcome of the permanent status negotiations. While noting that fact, the Government does not consider it appropriate or productive for Australia to interfere in an ongoing process of negotiation on issues of great difficulty, sensitivity and complexity which only the parties themselves can resolve through renewed dialogue.

(2) The Government is aware of reports that there may be private Australian involvement in providing funding settlement activity in the Occupied Territories. The Government has repeatedly urged all parties to the Middle East dispute to avoid and prevent actions which may lead to a heightening of tensions in the region.
(3) Under Australian law it is not illegal for Australian citizens to make donations to political or religious causes in Israel.
(4) The Government has not sought and will not seek to restrict private citizens from using private funds as they wish, so long as the activity remains legal.
(5) Such activity is not prohibited under Australian law.
(6) No. The Government has no interest in monitoring private funding activities which are not illegal under Australian law.

subdebateinfo.title: Office of the Employment Advocate: Staff
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2766)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 11 March 1998:

question.para: (1) What are the precise roles and responsibilities of employees of the Office of the Employment Advocate.

(2) Does the role of an employee of the Office of the Employment Advocate include the video taping and other forms of surveillance of persons involved in picket lines and other associated industrial action; if so, why.
(3) How many employees of the Office of the Employment Advocate are located in the Illawarra region, NSW.
(4) Has his attention been drawn to an industrial dispute between NSW Grain Corporation's Pivot management and the Australian Workers Union at Port Kembla, NSW.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Employees of the Office of the Employment Advocate (OEA) carry out functions outlined in 83BB of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 (`the Act'). Those functions are principally in relation to advising and assisting employers and employees in relation to rights and obligations under the Act; filing and approval of AWAs; investigating breaches of AWAs and of certain penalty provisions regarding AWAs; and investigating contraventions of the freedom of association provisions of the Act.

Staff carrying out compliance work are appointed as authorised officers under Section 83BG of the Act and as Inspectors under Section 84 of the Act. The role of authorised officers is to seek to ensure compliance with the Act, in particular the freedom of association and AWA provisions. The role of compliance officers appointed as inspectors is to ascertain whether certain provisions of the Act (namely provisions regarding coercion into Certified Agreements, payment of strike pay, and the provisions concerning right of entry) have been observed.

(2) The actions of OEA employees who have been appointed as authorised officers and/or inspectors are undertaken in accordance with sections 83BH and 86 of the Act respectively. No OEA officer has been involved in the videotaping of any industrial activity. Observation of picket lines or other industrial activity would only be undertaken if such observation was required to ascertain whether there had been a breach of a provision of the Act for which the OEA is responsible (eg. the freedom of association provisions).
(3) No officers are located in the Illawarra region. Officers based in Sydney are able to respond to complaints in the Illawarra region.
(4) Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 12 March 1998:

question.para: Is Airservices Australia proposing to privatise air traffic control, firefighting or other services at airports; if so, (a) which services at which airports and (b) what authorisation or approval has (i) he, (ii) the Board of Airservices or (iii) the Chief Executive Officer of Airservices provided.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Airservices Australia is a statutory authority that provides air traffic control, rescue and firefighting and other services at airports as prescribed in the Air Services Act 1995. The Airports Act, which was passed by the Parliament in 1996, provides for rescue and fire fighting services to be provided by a party other than Airservices, with the agreement of the Minister, and for the provision of air traffic control and navigation services and facilities by a third party under arrangement with Airservices.
I am not aware of any substantive discussions between airport lessee companies and Airservices on this issue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, upon notice, on 12 March 1998:

question.para: Did an incident occur at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport during the weekend of 28 February and 1 March 1998 in which an aircraft was forced to make an emergency landing as a result of engine failure; if so, (a) what were the circumstances of the incident, including the (i) type of aircraft involved, (ii) nature of the emergency, (iii) likely cause of the emergency and (iv) number of people in the aircraft, (b) was the aircraft (i) making a steep ascent, (ii) making a turn or (iii) over a residential area when the emergency occurred and (c) what steps have been taken to address the safety issues revealed by the incident.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (a) and (b) The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) is investigating an incident which occurred on 28 February 1998 at approximately 12:47 Eastern Summer Time at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The aircraft involved was a Boeing 767 operating a domestic scheduled passenger service from Sydney to Cairns.

Shortly after take off from Sydney runway 16R, the aircraft's right engine malfunctioned. The crew requested a return to Sydney. Because of local showers, the aircraft was radar vectored for an ILS approach to runway 16R where it landed without further incident. The aircraft stopped on the taxiway and the right engine was shut down and inspected by fire tenders. There was no evidence of fire and the aircraft taxied back to the gate where the passengers disembarked normally. The investigation will examine all of the relevant contributing factors and safety issues associated with this incident and a copy of the investigation report will be provided to the honourable member as soon as it becomes publicly available.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In 1997 (1997 being the last year of comprehensive data), 19 Australian universities had a faculty or department of history, 17 universities did not have a faculty or department of history.
